speaker: Presenter
text: Many people in this country are becoming increasingly worried about bull-fighting. They say it's not only cruel, vicious and immoral, but also blatantly unfair. The bull is heavy, violent, abusive and aggressive with four legs and great sharp teeth, whereas the bull-fighter is only a small, greasy Spaniard. Given this basic inequality what can be done to make bull-fighting safer? We asked Brigadier Arthur Farquar-Smith, Chairman of the British Well-Basically Club.

speaker: Brigadier
text: Well, basically it's quite apparent that these little dago chappies have got it all wrong. They prance round the bull like a lot of bally night club dancers looking like the Younger Generation or a less smooth version of the Lionel Blair Troupe, with much of the staccato rhythms of the Irving Davies Dancers at the height of their success. In recent years Pan's People have often recaptured a lyricism ... and what we must do now is to use devices like radar to locate the bull and SAM missiles fired from underground silos, to knock the bull over. Then I would send in Scottish boys with air cover to provide a diversion for the bull, whilst the navy came in round the back and finished him off. That to me would be bull-fighting and not this pansy kind of lyrical, evocative movement which George Balanchine and Martha Graham in the States and our very own Sadler's Wells ... Troops could also be used in an auxiliary role in international chess, where... What? ... oh...

speaker: Badger
text: I'll put the lights on again for a pound.

speaker: Voice Over
text: This is the planet Algon, fifth world in the system of Aldebaran, the Red Giant in the constellation of Sagittarius. Here an ordinary cup of drinking chocolate costs four million pounds, an immersion heater for the hot-water tank costs over six billion pounds, and a pair of split-crotch panties would be almost unobtainable. A simple rear window de-misting device for an 1100 costs eight thousand million billion pounds and a new element for an electric kettle like this would cost as much as the entire gross national product of the United States of America from 1770 to the year 2000, and even then they wouldn't be able to afford the small fixing ring which attaches it to the kettle.

speaker: M'Burke
text: Well, our computers have been working all day to analyse the dramatic information that's come in from this first ever intergalactic probe, Algon I ... ... and we're just getting an interesting development now, which is that attachments for rotary mowers - that is mowers that have a central circular blade - are... relatively inexpensive! Still in the region of nine to ten million pounds, but it does seem to indicate that Algon might be a very good planet for those with larger gardens ... or perhaps even an orchard that's been left for two years, needs some heavy work, some weeding... But we're now getting some live pictures through from Algon! Harry - Perhaps you could talk us through them.

speaker: Harry
text: Very little evidence of shopping facilities here .. there don't seem to be any large supermarkets. There may be some on-the-corner grocery stores behind those rocks, but it's difficult to tell from this angle. It does seem to suggest that most of the shopping here is by direct mail.

speaker: M'Burke
text: Of course the big question that everyone's asking here is, what about those split-crotch parities? Are they going to be unobtainable throughout the Universe or merely on Algon itself? Professor?

speaker: Professor
text: We must remember that Algon is over 75,000 miles wide. The probes come down to this area here and we're really only getting signals from a radius of only thirty or forty miles around the probe. Split-crotch panties, or indeed any items of what we scientists call, 'Sexy Underwear' or 'Erotic Lingerie' may be much more plentiful on other parts of the planet.

speaker: M'Burke
text: Professor, you were responsible for finding Scanty-Panties and Golden Goddess High-Lift Bras on planets which were never thought able to sustain life, and now that man has discovered a new galaxy do you think we're going to see underwear become even naughtier?

speaker: Professor
text: Oh naughtier and naughtier.

speaker: M'Burke
text: Well so much for that ... But of course, the probe itself has excited a great deal of interest... for it contains uranium-based dual transmission cells entirely re-charged by solar radiation, which can take off a bra and panties in less than fifteen seconds. It is, of course, the first piece of space hardware to be specially designed to undress ladies, and so there are bound to be some teething troubles ... such as how to cope with the combination of elastic-sided boots and tights.

speaker: M'Burke
text: But I think we're getting some pictures now from Algon itself, and it looks as though ... yes! The satellite has found a bird! The probe has struck crumpet and she looks pretty good too! Professor?

speaker: Professor
text: Ja - she's a real honey!

speaker: M'Burke
text: Well the pictures are a bit sporadic... I think probably... the solar radiation during the long journey to Algon... Hoy! Look! Oh dear, I'm sorry we've lost contact. We'll try and re-establish contact with Algon...

speaker: Badger
text: Hello... The BBC have offered me the sum of forty pence to read the credits of this show. Personally I thought they should have held out for the full seventy-five, but the BBC have explained to me about their financial difficulties and ... er ... I decided to accept the reduced offer... so ... the show was conceived, written and performed by... the usual lot... Also appearing were Carol Cleveland, Marie Anderson, Mrs Idle, Make-up - Madelaine Gaffney, Costume - Hazel Pethig, Animations by Terry Gilliam, Visual Effects Designer - Bernard Wilkie, Graphics - Bob Blagden, Film Cameraman - Alan Featherstone, Film Editor - Ray Millichope, Sound - Richard Chubb, Lighting - Bill Bailey, Designer - Bob Berk, Produced by Ian MacNaughton for 92p and a bottle of Bells whisky ... it was a BBC colour production. That's just it. I'd like to say if there are any BBC producers looking in who need people to read the credits for them, I would personally...

speaker: Pither
text: August 18th. Fell off near Bovey Tracey. The pump caught in my trouser leg.

speaker: Pither
text: The pump caught in my trouser leg, and my sandwiches were badly crushed.

speaker: Proprietor
text: 35p please.

speaker: Pither
text: These sandwiches, however, were an excellent substitute.

speaker: Driver
text: Give us ten woods, Barney.

speaker: Pither
text: Hello! It's funny how one can go through life, as I have, disliking bananas and being indifferent to cheese, and then be able to eat, and enjoy, a banana and cheese sandwich like this.

speaker: Proprietor
text: 35p please.

speaker: Pither
text: Ah! I have only a fifty. Do you have change?

speaker: Proprietor
text: Well I'll have a look, but I may have to go to the bank.

speaker: Pither
text: I'm most awfully sorry.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, what a stroke of luck. Well, all the very best. And thank you again for the excellent banana and cheese delicacy.

speaker: Pither
text: August 23rd. Fell off near Budleigh Salterton.

speaker: Pither
text: ...and the pump caught in my trouser leg... ...and that's how they were damaged... ...the eggs...you remember...the hard-boiled eggs I was telling you about...they were in a tupperware container, reputedly self-sealing, which fell open upon contact with the tarmacadam surface of the road.... ...the B489...the Dawlish road... That shouldn't really happen to a self-sealing container, should it? What do you keep your hard-boiled eggs in?

speaker: Pither
text: I think in future I shall lash them to the handlebars with adhesive tape...this should obviate a recurrence of the same problem...well I can't stop here all day...I'm on a cycling tour of North Cornwall. Must be off.

speaker: Pither
text: August 26th. Fell off near Ottery St Mary. The pump caught in my trouser leg. Decided to wear short trousers from now on.

speaker: Pither
text: Fell off near Tiverton. Perhaps a shorter pump is the answer.

speaker: Pither
text: Excuse me, madam, I wonder if you could tell me of a good bicycle shop in this village, where I could find either a means of adapting my present pump, or failing that, purchase a replacement?

speaker: Old lady
text: There's only one shop here.

speaker: Pither
text: What a stroke of luck. Now perhaps cycling will become less precarious.

speaker: Doctor
text: Yes? (a nurse puts her head round the door)

speaker: Nurse
text: A Mr Pither to see you, doctor. His bicycle pump got caught in his sock.

speaker: Doctor
text: Oh, thank you nurse, show him in please.

speaker: Nurse
text: This way, please.

speaker: Doctor
text: Morning.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, a very good morning to you too, Doctor

speaker: Doctor
text: Ah, I understand you had an accident?

speaker: Pither
text: Yes, my pump got...

speaker: Doctor
text: ...caught in your sock.

speaker: Pither
text: Absolutely. Yes. My fruit cake was damaged on one side.

speaker: Doctor
text: Well...

speaker: Pither
text: It's got grit all over it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Well now, are you in pain?

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, heavens no.

speaker: Doctor
text: Ah well, where were you hurt?

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, fortunately, I escaped without injury.

speaker: Doctor
text: Well what is the trouble?

speaker: Pither
text: Please, could you tell me the way to Iddesleigh?

speaker: Doctor
text: I'm a doctor, you know.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh yes, absolutely. Normally I would have asked a policeman or a minister of the Church, but finding no one available, I thought it better to consult a man with some professional qualifications, rather than rely on the possibly confused testimony of a passer-by.

speaker: Doctor
text: Oh alright. Take this to a chemist.

speaker: Pither
text: Thank you.

speaker: Pither
text: September 2nd. Did not fall off outside Iddesley.

speaker: Pither
text: Fell off in Tavistock.

speaker: Pither
text: My foot caught in my trouser leg and that's how the bottle broke.

speaker: Girl
text: Tell her today, you could ring her.

speaker: Man
text: I can't. I can't.

speaker: Pither
text: I said you'd never guess.

speaker: Man
text: Sixteen years we've been together. I can't just ring her up.

speaker: Girl
text: Well, if you can't do it now, you never will.

speaker: Pither
text: Do you like Tizer?

speaker: Man
text: What? No. No.

speaker: Girl
text: Do you want me or not, James? It's your decision.

speaker: Pither
text: I suppose it is still available in this area, is it?

speaker: Girl
text: Do you want me or not, James?

speaker: Man
text: What?

speaker: Pither
text: Tizer.

speaker: Girl
text: Yes or no.

speaker: Pither
text: Is it still available in this area?

speaker: Man
text: I don't know.

speaker: Girl
text: I see, in that case it's goodbye for ever, James.

speaker: Man
text: No! I mean yes!

speaker: Pither
text: Oh it is, is it?

speaker: Man
text: No.

speaker: Girl
text: Oh! You never could make up your mind.

speaker: Man
text: I can.... I have....

speaker: Girl
text: Goodbye James.

speaker: Man
text: No wait, Lucille!

speaker: Pither
text: Does your lovely daughter like Tizer? Eh?

speaker: Man
text: Lucille!

speaker: Pither
text: Wouldn't mind buying her a bottle of Tizer.... if it's available in this area, that is.

speaker: Man
text: Would you like me to show you the door?

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, that's extremely kind of you, but I saw it on the way in.

speaker: Man
text: You stupid, interfering little rat.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh! The very words of the garage mechanic in Bude!

speaker: Pither
text: I had just fallen off my bicycle, this is most kind of you, and my lemon curd tartlet had...

speaker: Man
text: Damn your lemon curd tartlet!

speaker: Pither
text: Just had a chat with your dad.

speaker: Pither
text: My rubber instep caught on the rear mudguard stanchion and...

speaker: Gulliver
text: Really? And what happened to the corned beef rolls?

speaker: Pither
text: The corned beef rolls squashed out of all...here, how did you know about the corned beef rolls?

speaker: Gulliver
text: I noticed them - or what remained of them - in the road. I noticed also that the lemon curd tart had sustained some superficial damage.

speaker: Pither
text: That's right. The curd had become...

speaker: Gulliver
text: Detached from the pastry base.

speaker: Pither
text: Absolutely right, yes.

speaker: Gulliver
text: Otherwise the contents of the sandwich box were relatively unharmed, although I detected small particles of bitumen in the chocolate kup kakes.

speaker: Pither
text: But they were wrapped in foil!

speaker: Gulliver
text: Not the hard chocolate top, I'm afraid.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, that's the bit I like.

speaker: Gulliver
text: The sausage roll, the crisps and ginger bisquit were unscathed.

speaker: Pither
text: How do you know so much about cycling?

speaker: Gulliver
text: Well, I'm making a special study of accidents involving food.

speaker: Pither
text: Really?

speaker: Gulliver
text: Yes, do you know that in our laboratories, we have developed a cheese sandwich that can withstand an impact of 4,000 pounds per square inch?

speaker: Pither
text: Good heavens!

speaker: Gulliver
text: Amazing, isn't it? We have also developed a tomato which can eject itself when an accident is imminent.

speaker: Pither
text: Even if it's inside an egg and tomato roll?

speaker: Gulliver
text: Anywhere! Even if it's in your stomach, and it senses an accident it will come up your throat and out of the window. Do you realise what this means?

speaker: Pither
text: Safer food?

speaker: Gulliver
text: Exactly! No longer will food be squashed, crushed and damaged, by the ignorance and stupidity of the driver! Whole picnics will be built to withstand the most enormous forces! Snacks will be safer than ever! An simple pot of salad dressing, treated in our laboratories, has been subjected to the impact of a 4,000 pound steam hammer every day for the last sixteen years and has it broken?

speaker: Pither
text: Er....well...

speaker: Gulliver
text: Yes, of course it has...but there are other ideas - the safety straps for sardines for instance.

speaker: Pither
text: Here, that tomato just ejected itself.

speaker: Gulliver
text: Really? It works! It works!

speaker: Pither
text: What a strange turn this cycling tour has taken. Mr Gulliver appears to have lost his memory and far from being interested in safer food is now convinced that he is Clodagh Rogers, the young girl singer. I am taking him for medical attention.

speaker: Pither
text: Is this the Casualty Department?

speaker: Nurse
text: Yes, that's right.

speaker: Nurse
text: And what can I do for you?

speaker: Pither
text: I am at present on a cycling tour of the North Cornwall area taking in Bude and...

speaker: Nurse
text: Could I have your name please?

speaker: Pither
text: Ah, my name is Pither.

speaker: Nurse
text: What?

speaker: Pither
text: P-I-T-H-E-R ...as in Brotherhood, but with PI instead of the BRO and no HOOD.

speaker: Nurse
text: I see...

speaker: Pither
text: I had just visited Taunton...

speaker: Nurse
text: Sh!

speaker: Pither
text: ...and was cycling north towards...

speaker: Nurse
text: Yes, where were you injured?

speaker: Pither
text: Just where the A397 Ilfracombe road meets the...

speaker: Nurse
text: On your ...

speaker: Pither
text: Ah no... it's not I who was injured, it's my friend.

speaker: Nurse
text: Tut... Name?

speaker: Pither
text: Pither.

speaker: Nurse
text: No, no, no, no. Your friend's name.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, Clodagh Rogers...

speaker: Nurse
text: Clodagh Rogers!?

speaker: Pither
text: Well only since about 4:30....

speaker: Nurse
text: Yes. I think you'd better talk to Doctor Wu... Doctor!

speaker: Doctor
text: What? Damn!

speaker: Nurse
text: Aaaaaagh!

speaker: Doctor
text: Now, what's the trouble?

speaker: Pither
text: I am on a cycling tour of...

speaker: Nurse
text: He he's had an accident.

speaker: Pither
text: I have friend who, as a result of his injuries thinks he is Clodagh Rogers.

speaker: Doctor
text: He what?

speaker: Pither
text: Well, what happened was...

speaker: Pither
text: September 4th. Well I never. We are now in the Alpes Maritimes region of Southern France. Clodagh seems more intent on reaching Moscow than on rehearsing her new BBC2 series with Buddy Rich and the Younger Generation... Oh hello!

speaker: Gulliver
text: We cannot stay here. We must leave immediately. There is a ship in Marseilles.

speaker: Pither
text: I did enjoy your song for Europe, Clodagh.

speaker: Gulliver
text: I have seen an agent in the town. My life is in danger.

speaker: Pither
text: Danger, Clodagh?

speaker: Gulliver
text: Stalin has always hated me.

speaker: Pither
text: No one hates you, Clodagh.

speaker: Gulliver
text: I will not let myself fall into the hands of these scum.

speaker: Pither
text: I think you should go and have a little lie down, my dear. There is a busy day tomorrow of concerts and promotional tours.

speaker: Gulliver
text: I. One of the founders of the greatest nation on earth. I! Whom Lenin has called his greatest friend.

speaker: M. Brun
text: Taisez-vous. Taisez-vous.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh dear.

speaker: Gulliver
text: I! Who have worked all my life that my people should live.

speaker: M. Brun
text: Taisez-vous. Qu'est-ce que le bruit? C'est impossible!

speaker: Pither
text: Er... my name is Pither.

speaker: M. Brun
text: Oh... you are English?

speaker: Pither
text: Er yes, that's right. I'm on a cycling tour of North Cornwall, taking in Bude...

speaker: Gulliver
text: I will not be defeated. I will return to my country to fight against this new tyranny!

speaker: Pither
text: This is Clodagh Rogers, the Irish-born girl singer.

speaker: Mme. Brun
text: Mais oui - c'est Clodagh Rogers - 'Jack-in-a-box'! I'm just a jack in a box, I know whenever love knocks... Genevieve! Gerard! C'est Clodagh Rogers la fameuse chanteuse Anglaise.

speaker: Gulliver
text: I will never surrender! I will never surrender!...

speaker: Genevieve
text: Excusez-moi Madame Clodagh. Ecrivez-vous votre nom dans mon livre des hommes célèbrites, s'il vous plait. Là, au-dessous de Denis Compton. Maman! Ce n'est pas la belle Clodagh.

speaker: Mme. Brun
text: Quoi?

speaker: Genevieve
text: C'est Trotsky le révolutionaire.

speaker: M. Brun
text: Trotsky!

speaker: Mme. Brun
text: Mais Trotsky ne chante pas.

speaker: M. Brun
text: Il chante un peu.

speaker: Mme. Brun
text: Mais pas professionalement. Qu'il pense de Lenin.

speaker: M. Brun
text: Ah! Lenin!! Quel chanteur: 'If I ruled the world'.

speaker: Gulliver
text: Lenin. My friend. I come.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh excuse her, she's not very well recently, pressure of work, laryngitis, you know...

speaker: M. Brun
text: Et aussi Monsieur Kerensky avec le 'Little White Bull', eh?

speaker: Mme. Brun
text: Formidable.

speaker: Gulliver
text: Lenin! I come! Lenin!

speaker: Frenchman
text: Je t'aime.

speaker: French Girl
text: Maurice! Regardez! C'est la chanteuse anglaise Clodagh Rogers.

speaker: Frenchman
text: Ah mais oui! Jacques dans la boîte

speaker: Pither
text: After several days I succeeded in tracking down my friend Mr Gulliver on the outskirts of Smolensk.

speaker: Military Man
text: Smolensk. 200 miles east of Minsk. 200 north of Kursk. 1500 miles west of Omsk.

speaker: Pither
text: Thank you.

speaker: Pither
text: Anyway, as we were so far from home, and as Mr Gulliver, still believing himself to be Trotsky, was very tired from haranguing the masses all the way from Monte Carlo,

speaker: Military Man
text: Monte Carlo. 100 miles south of Turin. 100 east of Pisa. 500 miles west of Bilbao.

speaker: Pither
text: Thank you. I decided to check...

speaker: Pither
text: I decided to check...

speaker: Pither
text: No, sorry you go on.

speaker: Pither
text: I decided to check him into a hotel while I visited the British Embassy to ask for help in returning to Cornwall.

speaker: Pither
text: And so we registered at the Smolensk Young Men's Anti-Christian Association.

speaker: Military Man
text: YMACA. Corner of Anti-Semitic Street and Pogrom Square.

speaker: Pither
text: Go away. No, not you. A single room for my friend please.

speaker: Desk Clerk
text: Yes, sir. Bugged or unbugged?

speaker: Gulliver
text: I think I'd be happier with a bugged one.

speaker: Desk Clerk
text: Right, one bugged with bath.

speaker: Pither
text: Well, just have a nice lie down, and I'll go to the Embassy.

speaker: Desk Clerk
text: Trotsky! My lack of God, it's Trotsky!

speaker: Gulliver
text: Comrades. Socialism is not a...

speaker: Pither
text: Excuse me. Is this the British Consulate?

speaker: Chinaman
text: Yes yes... si si...that is correctment. Yes... Piccadilly Circus, mini-skirt and Joe Lyons.

speaker: Pither
text: I wish to see the consul, please.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Yes, yes, speakee speakee... me Blitish consul.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh! You are Rear Admiral Sir Dudley Compton?

speaker: Chinaman
text: No. He died. He have heart attack and fell out of window onto exploding bomb, and was killed in a shooting accident. I...I his how you say...succ...sussor.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, successor.

speaker: Chinaman
text: I'm his successor, Mr Atkinson.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Would you like drinkee? Or game bingo?

speaker: Pither
text: Well.... A drink would be very nice.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Mr. Livingstone. Go and get sake.

speaker: Livingstone
text: Yes, Boss.

speaker: Chinaman
text: How is Tonblidge Wells? How I long to see again walls of famous Shakespeare-style theatre in Stlatford-on-Avon.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh well, I'm a West Country man myself, Mr. Atkinson.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Oh Texas - Arizona - Kit Carson Super Scout.

speaker: Pither
text: No. No. West of England... Cornwall.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Coron... worll...

speaker: Pither
text: Cornwall.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Coronworl...oh yes know Coronworl very well. Went to school there, mother and father live there, ah yes. Go many weekend parties and polo playing cards in blidge club. Belong many clubs in Coronworld.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Ah, Mr Livingstone thank you, sake and bakewells tart. Well, chaps, buttocks up!

speaker: Pither
text: Rather.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Now then er... er...

speaker: Pither
text: Ah, Pither.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Ah Mr Pither. We Blitish here in Smolensk velly intellested in cliket.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, cricket?

speaker: Chinaman
text: No, no...you not speak English velly wells. Not clicket - clicket...clicketty click...clicket...housey housey...er, bingo.

speaker: Pither
text: Bingo...

speaker: Chinaman
text: Oh bingo...bingo...bingo.

speaker: Livingstone
text: Bingo! Bingo!

speaker: Chinaman
text: Hsai! Solly. Our boys got velly excited.

speaker: Livingstone
text: Bingo.

speaker: Chinaman
text: Shut face! Mr Pither, perhaps you could put in a good word for so we could join a very smart bingo club in Coronworl.

speaker: Pither
text: Well, it's not really my line...

speaker: Chinaman
text: We all velly quiet at back, not say anything except shout 'Housey! Housey!'

speaker: Livingstone
text: Housey! Housey!

speaker: Maoists
text: Housey! Housey!

speaker: Chinese Hordes
text: Housey! Housey! Housey housey!

speaker: Chinaman
text: Hi skwwati niyhi, keo t'sin feh t'sdung, hih watai bingo cards!

speaker: Livingstone
text: Nihi watai bingo cards?

speaker: Chinaman
text: Nihi watai!

speaker: Livingstone
text: Ah so...

speaker: Chinaman
text: Now then, Mr Pither, tell me which better - Hackney Star Bingo or St. Albans Top Rank Suite?

speaker: Pither
text: Well, I was hoping that you could help me and my friend to get back to England as...you see we're on a cycling tour of North Cornwall...

speaker: All
text: Bingo, bingo, bingo...

speaker: Chinese Hordes
text: Bingo! Bingo! Bingo! Bingo!

speaker: Pither
text: Is Mr Trotsky in his room, please?

speaker: Desk Clerk
text: No. He has gone to Moscow.

speaker: Military Man
text: Moscow. 1500 miles south of...

speaker: Desk Clerk
text: Shut up!

speaker: Pither
text: Moscow!

speaker: Grip
text: Come with us, please.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, who are you?

speaker: Bag
text: Well we're not secret police anyway.

speaker: Wallet
text: That's for sure.

speaker: Grip
text: If anything we are ordinary Soviet systems with no particular interest in politics.

speaker: Bag
text: None at all. Come with us.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, where are you taking me?

speaker: Wallet
text: What do we tell him?

speaker: Grip
text: Don't tell him any secrets.

speaker: Bag
text: Agreed.

speaker: Grip
text: Tell him anything except that we are taking him to Moscow where Trotsky is reunited with the Central Committee.

speaker: Wallet
text: We're taking you to a clambake.

speaker: Pither
text: Oh a clambake! I've never been to one of those.

speaker: Grip
text: Right, let's go.

speaker: Bag
text: Who's giving the orders round here?

speaker: Grip
text: I am. I'm senior to you.

speaker: Bag
text: No, you're not. You're a greengrocer, I'm an insurance salesman.

speaker: Grip
text: Greengrocers are senior to insurance salesmen.

speaker: Wallet
text: Cool it. I'm an ice-cream salesmen and I am senior to both of you.

speaker: Bag
text: You're an ice-cream salesman? I thought you were a vetenarian.

speaker: Wallet
text: I got promoted. Let's go.

speaker: Bag
text: Taxi!

speaker: Taxi
text: Yes.

speaker: Bag
text: Drive us to Moscow.

speaker: Taxi
text: I have no a cab.

speaker: Wallet
text: Why not?

speaker: Taxi
text: I'm in the Secret Police.

speaker: General
text: ...Dostoievye useye tovarich trotsky borodina SUBTITLE: 'THIS IS THE MAN WHO BROUGHT OUR BELOVED TROTSKY BACK TO US' General Beluntanks dretsky mihai ovna isky Mr Reg Pither. SUBTITLE: 'FIRST MAY I PRESENT MR PITHER FROM WEST OF ENGLAND' General Shi muska di scensand dravenka oblomov Engleska Solzhenitzhin. SUBTITLE: 'FORGIVE ME IF I CONTINUE IN ENGLISH IN ORDER TO SAVE TIME' General And now, Comrades, the greatest moment of the day, the moment when I ask you to welcome the return of one of Russia's greatest heroes, creator of the Red Army, Lenin's greatest friend, Lev Davidovich Trotsky! Gulliver Comrades. Bolsheviks. Friends of the Revolution. I have returned. The bloodstained shadow of Stalinist repression is past. I bring you new light of Permanent Revolution . Comrades, I may once have been ousted from power, I may have been expelled from the party in 1927, I may have been deported in 1929 but I'm just an old-fashioned girl, with an old-fashioned mind. Comrades, I don't want to destroy in order to build, I don't want a state founded on hate and division I want an old-fashioned house with an old-fashioned fence, and an old-fashioned millionaire. Pither Our friend Mr Gulliver was clearly undergoing another change of personality. General So! You have duped us. You shall pay for this. Guards, seize him. General Shall I seize him too? Senior General No, I think we'll have to keep him, he's going down well. General He's more fun than he used to be. Senior General He's loosened up a lot. This is an old Lenin number. Pither April 26th. Thrown into Russian cell. Severely damaged my Mars bar. Shall I ever see Bude Bus station again? Oh excuse me... Pither What a pleasant exercise yard. How friendly they were all being. Officer Cigarettes? Pither Oh, no thank you I don't smoke. Pither After a few minutes I perceived a line of gentlemen with rifles. They were looking in my direction... I looked around but could not see the target. Officer Blindfold? Pither No thank you, no. Officer Slowotny! Grydenka... Verschnitzen. Messenger Nyet! Nyet! Nyet! Officer A telegram? From the Kremlin! The Central Committee! It says...'Carry on with the execution'. Verschnitzen... Pither Now I was really for it. Officer How could you miss? Soldier He moved. Officer Shut up! Go and practise. I'm so sorry. Do you mind waiting in your cell? Pither What a stroke of luck. My Crunchie was totally intact. I settled down to a quick intermeal snack... Officer Next time. Definitely! Now then, how many of them have been injured? Oh God... Pither As I lay dwon to the sound of the Russian gentlemen practising their shooting, I realised I was in a bit of a pickle. My heart sank as I realised I should never see the Okehampton by-pass again... Mother Come on, dear. Wake up dear. Pither Mother! Mother Come on dear. Pither So, it was all a dream. Mother No dear, is the dream, you're still in the cell. Officer OK, we're going to have another try. I think we've got it now. My boys have been looking down the wrong bit, you see. Pither Oh no, look, you've got to look down the bit there. Officer Oh I thought you had to look down that bit. Pither No, no, you've got to look down that bit, or you won't hit anything. Officer Alright, we'll give it a whirl. Guards, seize him. Officer Listen. You've got to look down this bit. Compère Osledi Osledi. Compère Eartha Kitt! Heath's Voice Trade Union leaders - I would say this - we've done our part. Now, on behalf of the community, we have a right to expect you, the Trade Union leaders, to do yours. Gulliver That turnip's certainly not safe. Oh no! Mr Pither! Mr Pither! Gulliver Mr Pither! Mr Pither! Gulliver Mr Pither! Pither's Voice Here! Pither Gulliver. Gulliver Pither! What a stroke of luck. Pither Well yes and no. CAPTION: 'SCENE MISSING' Pither Phew, what an amazing escape. Well goodbye, Reginald. Gulliver Goodbye, Mr Pither, and good luck with the tour! Hey, I think he's finally gone! Second Monster Ooh yes! First Monster Ready, Maurice? Second Monster Right-ho, Kevin. Let's go. First Monster All right, maestro, hit it!

speaker: General
text: ...Dostoievye useye tovarich trotsky borodina

speaker: General
text: Beluntanks dretsky mihai ovna isky Mr Reg Pither.

speaker: General
text: Shi muska di scensand dravenka oblomov Engleska Solzhenitzhin.

speaker: General
text: And now, Comrades, the greatest moment of the day, the moment when I ask you to welcome the return of one of Russia's greatest heroes, creator of the Red Army, Lenin's greatest friend, Lev Davidovich Trotsky!

speaker: Gulliver
text: Comrades. Bolsheviks. Friends of the Revolution. I have returned. The bloodstained shadow of Stalinist repression is past. I bring you new light of Permanent Revolution . Comrades, I may once have been ousted from power, I may have been expelled from the party in 1927, I may have been deported in 1929 but I'm just an old-fashioned girl, with an old-fashioned mind. Comrades, I don't want to destroy in order to build, I don't want a state founded on hate and division I want an old-fashioned house with an old-fashioned fence, and an old-fashioned millionaire.

speaker: Pither
text: Our friend Mr Gulliver was clearly undergoing another change of personality.

speaker: General
text: So! You have duped us. You shall pay for this. Guards, seize him.

speaker: General
text: Shall I seize him too?

speaker: Senior General
text: No, I think we'll have to keep him, he's going down well.

speaker: General
text: He's more fun than he used to be.

speaker: Senior General
text: He's loosened up a lot. This is an old Lenin number.

speaker: Pither
text: April 26th. Thrown into Russian cell. Severely damaged my Mars bar. Shall I ever see Bude Bus station again? Oh excuse me...

speaker: Pither
text: What a pleasant exercise yard. How friendly they were all being.

speaker: Officer
text: Cigarettes?

speaker: Pither
text: Oh, no thank you I don't smoke.

speaker: Pither
text: After a few minutes I perceived a line of gentlemen with rifles. They were looking in my direction... I looked around but could not see the target.

speaker: Officer
text: Blindfold?

speaker: Pither
text: No thank you, no.

speaker: Officer
text: Slowotny! Grydenka... Verschnitzen.

speaker: Messenger
text: Nyet! Nyet! Nyet!

speaker: Officer
text: A telegram? From the Kremlin! The Central Committee! It says...'Carry on with the execution'. Verschnitzen...

speaker: Pither
text: Now I was really for it.

speaker: Officer
text: How could you miss?

speaker: Soldier
text: He moved.

speaker: Officer
text: Shut up! Go and practise. I'm so sorry. Do you mind waiting in your cell?

speaker: Pither
text: What a stroke of luck. My Crunchie was totally intact. I settled down to a quick intermeal snack...

speaker: Officer
text: Next time. Definitely! Now then, how many of them have been injured? Oh God...

speaker: Pither
text: As I lay dwon to the sound of the Russian gentlemen practising their shooting, I realised I was in a bit of a pickle. My heart sank as I realised I should never see the Okehampton by-pass again...

speaker: Mother
text: Come on, dear. Wake up dear.

speaker: Pither
text: Mother!

speaker: Mother
text: Come on dear.

speaker: Pither

You sit there on your loathsome, spotty behinds squeezing blackheads, not caring a tinker's cuss about the struggling artist. You excrement! You lousy hypocritical whining toadies with your lousy colour TV sets and your Tony Jacklin golf clubs and your bleeding masonic handshakes! speaker: From these glens and scars, the sound of the coot and the moorhen is seldom absent. Nature sits in stern mastery over these rocks and crags. The rush of the mountain stream, the bleat of the sheep, and the broad, clear Highland skies, reflected in turn and loch ...
text: ... form the breathtaking backdrop against which Ewan McTeagle writes such poems as 'Lend us a quid till the end of the week'.

speaker: Voice Over
text: But it was with more simple, homespun verses that McTeagle's unique style first flowered.

speaker: McTeagle
text: If you could see your way to lending me sixpence. I could at least buy a newspaper. That's not much to ask anyone.

speaker: Voice Over
text: One woman who remembers McTeagle as a young friend - Lassie O'Shen.

speaker: Lassie
text: Mr MeTeagle wrote me two poems, between the months of January and April 1969...

speaker: Interviewer
text: Could you read us one?

speaker: Lassie
text: Och, I dinna like to... they were kinda personal... but I will. 'To Ma Own beloved Lassie. A poem on her 17th Birthday. Lend us a couple of bob till Thursday. I'm absolutely skint. But I'm expecting a postal order and I can pay you back as soon as it comes. Love Ewan.'

speaker: Sound Man
text: Beautiful.

speaker: Limbo
text: Since then, McTeagle has developed and widened his literary scope. Three years ago he concerned himself with quite small sums - quick bits of ready cash: sixpences, shillings, but more recently he has turned his extraordinary literary perception to much larger sums - fifteen shillings, £4.12.6 ... even nine guineas ... But there is still nothing to match the huge sweep ... the majestic power of what is surely his greatest work: 'Can I have fifty pounds to mend the shed?'.

speaker: Ian

speaker: Limbo
text: There seems to be no end to McTeagle's poetic invention. 'My new cheque book hasn't arrived' was followed up by the brilliantly allegorical 'What's twenty quid to the bloody Midland Bank?' and more recently his prizewinning poem to the Arts Council: 'Can you lend me one thousand quid?'

speaker: David

Also I would like to point out that the BALPA spokesman who complained about aeronautical inaccuracies was himself wearing a captain's hat, whereas he only had lieutenant's stripes on the sleeves of his jacket. Also, in the Inverness pantomime last Christmas, the part of Puss in Boots was played by a native of New Guinea with a plate in her lip, so that every time Dick Whittington gave her a French kiss, he got the back of his throat scraped.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Hello. Tonight on 'Face the Press' we're going to examine two different views of contemporary things. On my left is the Minister for Home Affairs who is wearing a striking organza dress in pink tulle, with matching pearls and a diamante collar necklace. The shoes are in brushed pigskin with gold clasps, by Maxwell of Bond Street. The hair is by Roger, and the whole ensemble is crowned by a spectacular display of Christmas orchids. And on my right - putting the case against the Government - is a small patch of brown liquid ... which could be creosote or some extract used in industrial varnishing. Good evening. Minister, may I put the first question to you? In your plan, 'A Better Britain For Us', you claimed that you would build 88,000 million, billion houses a year in the Greater London area alone. In fact, you've built only three in the last fifteen years. Are you a bit disappointed with this result?

speaker: Presenter
text: Good evening. On 'Ethel the Frog' tonight we look at violence. The violence of British Gangland. Last Tuesday a reign of terror was ended when the notorious Piranha brothers, Doug and Dinsdale , after one of the most extraordinary trials in British legal history, were sentenced to four hundred years imprisonment for crimes of violence. Tonight Ethell the Frog examinesthe rise to power of the Piranhas, the methods they used to subjugate rival gangs and their subsequent tracking down and capture by the brilliant Superintendent Harry 'Snapper' Organs of Q Division. Doug and Dinsdale Pirenha were born, on probation, in this small house in Kipling Road, Southwark, the eldest sons in a family of sixteen. Their father Arthur Piranha, a scrap-metal dealer and TV quizmaster, was well known to the police, and a devout Catholic. In January 1928 he had married Kitty Malone, an up-and-coming Eastend boxer. Doug was bornin February 1929 and Dinsdale two weeks later; and again a week after that. Their next door neighbour was Mrs April Simnel.

speaker: Mrs Simmel
text: Kipling Road was a typical sort of Eastend street, people were in and out of each other's houses with each other's property all day. They were a cheery lot.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Was it a terribly violent area?

speaker: Mrs Simmel
text: Oh ho......yes. Cheerful and violent. I remember Doug was very keen on boxing, until he learned to walk, then he took up putting the boot in the groin. Oh he was very interested in that. His mother had such trouble getting him to come in for his tea. He'd be out there putting his little boot in, you know, bless him. You know kids were very different then. They didn't have their heads filled with all this Cartesian dualism.

speaker: Voice Over
text: At the age of fifteen Doug and Dinsdale started attending the Ernest Pythagoras Primary School in Clerkenwell.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Anthony Viney. You taught the Piranha brothers English. What do you remember most about them?

speaker: Interviewer
text: ...Anthoney Viney.

speaker: Presenter
text: When the Piranhas left school they were called up but were found by an Army Board to be too unstable even for National Service. Denied the opportunity to use their talents in the service of their country, they began to operate what they called 'The Operation'. They would select a victim and then threaten to beat him up if he paid the so-called protection money. Four months later they started another operation which the called 'The Other Operation'. In this racket they selected another victim and threatened to beat him up if he pay them. One month later they hit upon 'The Other Other Operation'. In this the victim was threatened that if he didn't pay them, they would beat him up. This for the Piranha brothers was the turning point.

speaker: Organs
text: Doug and Dinsdale Piranha now formed a gang, which the called 'The Gang' and used terror to take over night clubs, billiard halls, gaming casinos and race tracks. When they tried to take over the MCC they were for the only time in their lives, slit up a treat. As their empire spread however, we in Q Division were keeping tabs on their every move by reading the colour supplements.

speaker: Presenter
text: A small-time operator who fell foul of Dinsdale Piranha was Vince Snetterton-Lewis.

speaker: Vince
text: Well one day I was sitting at home threatening the kids, and I looked out of the hole in the wall and sees this tank drive up and one of Dinsdale's boys gets out and he comes up, all nice and friendly like, and says Dinsdale wants to have a talk with me. So he chains me to the back of the tank and takes me for a scrape round to Dinsdale's. And Dinsdale's there in the conversation pit with Doug and Charles Paisley, the baby crusher, and a couple of film producers and a man they called 'Kierkegaard', who just sat there biting the heads of whippets and Dinsdale sayd 'I hear you've been a naughty boy Clement' and he splits me nostrils open and saws me leg off and pulls me liver out, and I said my name's not Clement and then he loses his temper and nails my head to the floor.

speaker: Vince

speaker: Presenter
text: Clearly Dinsdale inspired tremendous loyalty and terror amongst his business associates, but what was he really like?

speaker: Gloria
text: I walked out with Dinsdale on many occasions and found him a most charming and erudite companion. He was wont to introduce one to eminent persons, celebrated American singers, members of the aristocracy and other gang leaders.

speaker: Interviewer
text: How had he met them?

speaker: Gloria
text: Through his work for charity. He took a warm interest in Boys' Clubs, Sailors' Homes, Choristers' Associations, Scouting Jamborees and of course the Household Cavalry.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Was there anything unusual about him?

speaker: Gloria
text: I should say not. Dinsdale was a perfectly normal person in every way. Except is as much as he was convinced that he was being watched by a giant hedgehog whom he referred to as Spiny Norman.

speaker: Interviewer
text: How big was Norman supposed to be?

speaker: Gloria
text: Normally he was wont to be about twelve feet from nose to tail, but when Dinsdale was depressed Norman could be anything up to eight hundred yards long. When Norman was about, Dinsdale would go very quiet and his nose would swell up and his teeth would start moving about and he'd become very violent and claim that he'd laid Stanley Baldwin. Dinsdale was a gentleman. And what's more he knew how to treat a female impersonator.

speaker: Criminologist
text: It is easy for us to judge Dinsdale Piranha too harshly. After all he only did what many of us simply dream of doing... I'm sorry. After all a murderer is only an extroverted suicide. Dinsdale was a looney, but he was a happy looney. Lucky bastard.

speaker: Presenter
text: Most of the strange tales concern Dinsdale, but what about Doug? One man who met him was Luigi Vercotti.

speaker: Vercotti
text: Well, I had been running a successful escort agency - high class, no really, high class girls - we didn't have any of that. That was right out. And I decided. Excuse me Hello......no, not now......shtoom...shtoom....right......yes, we'll have the ready for you at midnight.......the watch.....the ....yes, right-oh, bye-bye mother Anyway I decided then to open a high-class night club for the gentry at Biggleswade with International cuisine, cooking, top-line acts, and not a cheap clip joint for picking up tarts, that was right out, I deny that completely, and one night Dinsdale walked in with a couple of big lads, one of whom was carrying a tactical nuclear missile. They said I'd bought one of their fruit machines and would I pay for it.

speaker: Interviewer
text: How much did they want?

speaker: Vercotti
text: Three quarters of a million pounds. Then they went out.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Why didn't you call the police?

speaker: Vercotti
text: Well I had noticed that the lad with the thermo-nuclear device was the Chief Constable for the area. Anyway a week later they came back, said that the cheque had bounced and that I had to see Doug.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Doug?

speaker: Vercotti
text: Doug I was terrified of him. Everyone was terrified of Doug. I've seen grown men pull their own heads off rather than see Doug. Even Dinsdale was frightened of Doug.

speaker: Interviewer
text: What did he do?

speaker: Vercotti
text: He used sarcasm. He knew all the tricks, dramatic irony, metaphor, bathos, puns, parody, litotes and satire.

speaker: Presenter
text: By a combination of violence and sarcasm, the Piranha brothers by February 1966 controlled London and the South East. In February, though, Dinsdale made a big mistake.

speaker: Gloria
text: Latterly Dinsdale had become increasingly worried about Spiny Norman. He had come to the conclusion that Norman slept in an aeroplane hangar at Luton Airport.

speaker: Presenter
text: And so on February 22nd 1966, at Luton airport... Even the police began to sit up and take notice.

speaker: Organs
text: The Piranhas realized they had gone too far and that the hunt was on. They went into hiding and I decided on a subtle approach, viz some form of disguise, as the old helmet and boots are a bit of a giveaway. Luckily my years with Bristol Rep. stood me in good stead, as I assumed a bewildering variety of disguises. I tracked them to Cardiff, posing as the Reverend Smiler Egret. Hearing they'd gone back to London, I assumed the identity of a pork butcher, Brian Stoats. On my arrival in London, I discovered they had returned to Cardiff, I followed as Gloucester from 'King Lear'. Acting on a hunch I spent several months in Buenos Aires as Blind Pew, returning through the Panama Canal as Ratty, in 'Toad of Toad Hall'. Back in Cardiff, I relived my triumph as Sancho Panza in 'Man of la Mancha' which the 'Bristol Evening Post' described as 'a glittering performance of rare perception', although the 'Bath Chronicle' was less than enthusiastic. In fact it gave me a right panning. I quote...

It's an identical situation, we have with 'ship' and 'boat' but not the same as we have with 'bow' and 'bough' , they're spelt differently, mean different things but sound the same. But the real question remains. What is the solution, if any, to this problem? What can we do? What am I saying? Why am I sitting in this chair? Why am I on this programme? text: Good afternoon and welcome to Hurlingham Park. You join us just as the competitors are running out onto the field on this lovely winter's afternoon here, with the going firm underfoot and very little sign of rain. Well it certainly looks as though we're in for a splendid afternoon's sport in this the 127th Upperclass Twit of the Year Show. Well the competitors will be off in a moment so let me just identify for you. Vivian Smith-Smythe-Smith has an O-level in chemo-hygiene. Simon-Zinc-Trumpet-Harris, married to a very attractive table lamp. Nigel Incubator-Jones, his best friend is a tree, and in his spare time he's a stockbroker. Gervaise Brook-Hampster is in the Guards, and his father uses him as a wastepaper basket. And finally Oliver St John-Mollusc, Harrow and the Guards, thought by many to be this year's outstanding twit. Now they're moving up to the starting line, there's a jolly good crowd here today. Now they're under starter's orders ... and they're off! Ah no, they're not. No they didn't realize they were supposed to start. Never mind, we'll soon sort that out, the judge is explaining it to them now. I think Nigel and Gervaise have got the idea. All set to go. Oh, and they're off and it's a fast start this year. Oliver St John-Mollusc running a bit wide there and now they're coming into their first test, the straight line. They've got to walk along this straight line without failing over and Oliver's over at the back there, er, Simon's coming through quite fast on the outside, I think Simon and Nigel, both of them coming through very fast. There's Nigel there. No. Three, I'm sorry, and on the outside there's Gervaise coming through just out of shot and now, the position... Simon and Vivian at the front coming to the matchbox jump.. three layers of matchboxes to clear... and Simon's over and Vivian's over beautifully, oh and the jump of a lifetime - if only his father could understand. Here's Nigel ... and now Gervaise is over he's, er, Nigel is over, and it's Gervaise, Gervaise is going to jump it, is it, no he's jumped the wrong way, there he goes, Nigel's over, beautifully. Now it's only Oliver. Oliver ... and Gervaise... oh bad luck. And now it's Kicking the Beggar. Simon's there and he's putting the boot in, and not terribly hard, but he's going down and Simon can move on. Now Vivian's there. Vivian is there and waiting for a chance. Here he comes, oh a piledriver, a real piledriver, and now Simon's on No. l, Vivian 2, Nigel 3, Gervaise on 4 and Oliver bringing up the rear. Ah there's Oliver , there's Oliver now, he's at the back. I think he's having a little trouble with his old brain injury, he's going to have a go, no, no, bad luck, he's up, he doesn't know when he's beaten, this boy, he doesn't know when he's winning either. He doesn't have any sort of sensory apparatus. Oh there's Gervaise and he's putting the boot in there and he's got the beggar down and the steward's giving him a little bit of advice, yes, he can move on now, he can move on to the Hunt Photograph. He's off, Gervaise is there and Oliver's still at the back having trouble with the matchboxes. Now here's the Hunt Ball Photograph and the first here's Simon, he's going to enjoy a joke with Lady Arabella Plunkett. She hopes to go into films, and Vivian's through there and, er, Nigel's there enjoying a joke with Lady Sarah Pencil Farthing Vivian Streamroller Adams Pie Biscuit Aftershave Gore Stringbottom Smith. And there's, there's Simon now in the sports car, he's reversed into the old woman, he's caught her absolutely beautifully. Now he's going to accelerate forward there to wake up the neighbour. There's Vivian I think, no Vivian's lost his keys, no there's Vivian, he's got the old woman, slowly but surely right in the midriff, and here he is. Here he is to wake up the neighbour now. Simon right in the lead, comfortably in the lead, but he can't get this neighbour woken up. He's slamming away there as best he can. He's getting absolutely no reaction at all. There, he's woken him up and Simon's through. Here comes Vivian, Vivian to slam the door, and there we are back at the Hunt Ball, I think that's Gervaise there, that's Gervaise going through there, and here, here comes Oliver, brave Oliver. Is he going to make it to the table, no I don't think he is, yes he is, he did it, ohh. And the crowd are rising to him there,and there I can see, who is that there, yes that's Nigel, Nigel has woken the neighbour - my God this is exciting. Nigel's got very excited and he's going through and here comes Gervaise. Gervaise, oh no this is, er, out in the front there is Simon who is supposed to insult the waiter and he's forgotten. And Oliver has run himself over, what a great twit! And now here comes Vivian, Vivian to insult the waiter, and he is heaping abuse on him, and he is humiliating him, there and he's gone into the lead. Simon's not with him, no Vivian's in front of him at the bar. Simon's got to get under this bar and this is extremely difficult as it requires absolutely expert co-ordination between mind and body. No Vivian isn't there. Here we go again and Simon's fallen backwards. Here's Nigel, he's tripped, Nigel has tripped, and he's under and Simon fails again, er, here is Gervaise, and Simon is through by accident. Here's Gervaise to be the last one over, there we are, here's Nigel right at the head of the field, and now he's going to shoot the rabbit, and these rabbits have been tied to the ground, and they're going to be a bit frisky, and this is only a one-day event. And they're blazing away there. They're not getting quite the results that they might, Gervaise is in there trying to bash it to death with the butt of his rifle, and I think Nigel's in there with his bare hands, but they're not getting the results that they might, but it is a little bit misty today and they must be shooting from a range of at least one foot. But they've had a couple of hits there I think, yes, they've had a couple of hits, and the whole field is up again and here they are. They're coming up to the debs, Gervaise first, Vivian second, Simon third. And now they've got to take the bras off from the front, this is really difficult, this is really the most, the most difficult part of the entire competition, and they're having a bit of trouble in there I think, they're really trying now and the crowd is getting excited, and I think some of the twits are getting rather excited too. Vivian is there, Vivian is coming through, Simon's in second place, and, no there's Oliver, he's not necessarily out of it. There goes Nigel, no he's lost something, and Gervaise running through to this final obstacle. Now all they have to do here to win the title is to shoot themselves. Simon has a shot. Bad luck, he misses. Nigel misses. Now there's Gervaise, and Gervaise has shot himself - Gervaise is Upperclass Twit of the Year. There's Nigel, he's shot Simon by mistake, Simon is back up and there's Nigel, Nigel's shot himself: Nigel is third in this fine and most exciting Upperclass Twit of the Year Show I've ever seen. Nigel's clubbed himself into fourth place. And so the final result: The Upperclass Twit of the Year - Gervaise Brook-Hampster of Kensington and Weybridge; runner up - Vivian Smith-Smythe-Smith of Kensington; and third - Nigel Incubator-Jones of Henley. Well there'll certainly be some car door slamming in the streets of Kensington tonight.

Louise's hernia has been confirmed, and Jim, Bob's brother, has run over the editor of the 'Lancet' on his way to see Jenny, a freelance Pagoda designer. On the other side of the continent Napoleon still broods over the smouldering remains of a city he had crossed half the earth to conquer...

speaker: Interviewer
text: From the plastic arts we turn to football. Last night in the Stadium of Light, Jarrow, we witnessed the resuscitation of a great footballing tradition, when Jarrow United came of age, in a European sense, with an almost Proustian display of modern existentialist football. Virtually annihilating by midfield moral argument the now surely obsolescent catennachio defensive philosophy of Signor Alberto Fanffino. Bologna indeed were a side intellectually out argued by a Jarrow team thrusting and bursting with aggressive Kantian positivism and outstanding in this fine Jarrow team was my man of the match, the arch-thinker, free scheming, scarcely ever to be curbed, midfield cognoscento, Jimmy Buzzard.

text: It just says 'We would like you to be in a sketch. You are standing at a counter. When the sketch starts you go off. Yours faithfully, Lord Hill.'

text: Oh I'll look after the cat. Goodness me, Mrs Newman's eldest never worried about the cat when he went off to do 'The Sweet Bird of Youth'.

speaker: Wife

speaker: Unction
text: Well that was a bit of fun wasn't it. Ha, ha, ha. And a special good evening to . Not just an ordinary good evening like you get from all the other announcers, but a special good evening from to . Well, what have we got next? This fun isn't it. Look, I'm sorry if I'm interrupting anything that any of you may be doing at home, but I want you to think of me as an old queen. , ha, ha, ha. Well, let's see what we've got next. In a few moments 'It's A Tree' and in the chair as usual is Arthur Tree, and starring in the show will be a host of star guests as his star guests. And then at 9.30 we've got another rollocking half hour of laughter-packed squalor with 'Yes it's the Sewage Farm Attendants'. And this week Dan falls into a vat of human dung with hilarious consequences. Ha, ha, ha. But now it's the glittering world of show business with Arthur Tree...

speaker: Tree
text: Hello. Hello people, and welcome to 'It's a Tree'. We have some really exiting guests for you this evening. A fabulous spruce, back from a tour of Holland, three gum trees making their first appearance in this country, scots pine and the conifers, and Elm Tree Bole - there you go, can't be bad - an exiting new American plank, a rainforest and a bucket of sawdust giving their views on teenage violence, and an unusual guest for this programme, a piece of laminated plastic.

speaker: Plastic
text: Hi there!

speaker: Tree
text: But first, will you please, please welcome - a block of wood.

speaker: Tree
text: Well, er, thanks Tree. I've got to pay the rent.

speaker: Tree
text: Ha, ha, ha, ha, super. Well, what have you been doing, Block?

speaker: Block
text: Well I've just been starring in several major multi-million dollar international films, and, during breaks on the set, I've been designing a Cathedral, doing wonderful unpublicized work for charity, er, finishing my history of the world, of course, pulling the birds, er, photographing royalty on the loo, averting World War Three - can't be bad - and, er learning to read.

speaker: Tree
text: The full Renaissance bit, really...super, super. Well I've got to stop you there Block I'm afraid, because we've got someone who's been doing cabaret in the New Forest. From America, will you welcome please a Chippendale writing desk.

speaker: Chip
text: Thank you Mr Tree. And I'd like to do a few impressions of some of my favourite Englishmen. First off. Long John Silver. Augh, Jim boy. Augh. And now Edward Heath. Hello sailor. Now a short scene from a play by Harold Splinter.

speaker: Compère
text: Wasn't that just great, ladies and gentlemen, wait a minute we've got something else I just know you're going to love. Yes sir, coming right up - the Vocational Guidance Counsellor Sketch.

speaker: Voices Singing
text: Vocational guidance counsellor ... vocational guidance counsellor ... vocational guidance counsellor ... etc.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Ah Mr Anchovy. Do sit down.

speaker: Anchovy
text: Thank you. Take the weight off the feet, eh?

speaker: Counsellor
text: Yes, yes.

speaker: Anchovy
text: Lovely weather for the time of year, I must say.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Enough of this gay banter. And now Mr Anchovy, you asked us to advise you which job in life you were best suited for.

speaker: Anchovy
text: That is correct, yes.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Well I now have the results here of the interviews and the aptitude tests that you took last week, and from them we've built up a pretty clear picture of the sort of person that you are. And I think I can say, without fear of contradiction, that the ideal job for you is chartered accountancy.

speaker: Anchovy
text: But I a chartered accountant.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Jolly good. Well back to the office with you then.

speaker: Anchovy
text: No! No! No! You don't understand. I've been a chartered accountant for the last twenty years. I want a new job. Something that will let me .

speaker: Counsellor
text: Well chartered accountancy is rather exciting isn't it?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Exciting? No it's . It's dull. Dull. . My God it's dull, it's so desperately dull and tedious and stuffy and boring and des-per-ate-ly DULL.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Well, er, yes Mr Anchovy, but you see your report here says that you are an extremely dull person. You see, our experts describe you as an appallingly dull fellow, unimaginative, timid, lacking in initiative, spineless, easily dominated, no sense of humour, tedious company and irrepressibly drab and awful. And whereas in most professions these would be considerable drawbacks, in chartered accountancy they are a positive boon.

speaker: Anchovy
text: But don't you see, I came here to find a new job, a new life, a new to my existence. Can't you help me?

speaker: Counsellor
text: Well, do you have any idea of what you want to do?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Yes, yes I have.

speaker: Counsellor
text: What?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Lion taming.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Well yes. Yes. Of course, it's a bit of a jump isn't it? I mean, er, chartered accountancy to lion taming in one go. You don't think it might be better if you worked your way lion taming, say, via banking?

speaker: Anchovy
text: No, no, no, no. No. I don't want to wait. At nine o'clock tomorrow I want to be in there, taming.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Fine, fine. But do you, do you have any qualifications?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Yes, I've got a hat.

speaker: Counsellor
text: A hat?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Yes, a hat. A lion taming hat. A hat with 'lion tamer' on it. I got it at Harrods. And it lights up saying 'lion tamer' in great big neon letters, so that you can tame them after dark when they're less stroppy.

speaker: Counsellor
text: I see, I see.

speaker: Anchovy
text: And you can switch it off during the day time, and claim reasonable wear and tear as allowable professional expenses under paragraph 335C...

speaker: Counsellor
text: Yes, yes, yes, I do follow, Mr Anchovy, but you see the snag is... if I now call Mr Chipperfield and say to him, 'look here, I've got a forty-five-year-old chartered accountant with me who wants to become a lion tamer', his first question is not going to be 'does he have his own hat?' He's going to ask what sort of experience you've had with lions.

speaker: Anchovy
text: Well I ... I've seen them at the zoo.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Good, good, good.

speaker: Anchovy
text: Lively brown furry things with short stumpy legs and great long noses. I don't know what all the fuss is about, I could tame one of those. They look pretty tame to start with.

speaker: Counsellor
text: And these, er, these lions ... how high are they?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Well they're about so high, you know. They don't frighten me at all.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Really. And do these lions eat ants?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Yes, that's right.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Er, well, Mr Anchovy ... I'm afraid what you've got hold of there is an anteater.

speaker: Anchovy
text: A what?

speaker: Counsellor
text: An anteater. Not a lion. You see a lion is a huge savage beast, about five feet high, ten feet long, weighing about four hundred pounds, running forty miles per hour, with masses of sharp pointed teeth and nasty long razor-sharp claws that can rip your belly open before you can say 'Eric Robinson', and they look like this.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Time enough I think for a piece of wood.

speaker: Voice Over
text: The larch.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Now, shall I call Mr Chipperfield?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Er, no, no, no. I think your idea of making the transition to lion taming via easy stages, say via insurance...

speaker: Counsellor
text: Or banking.

speaker: Anchovy
text: Or banking, yes, yes, banking that's a man's life, isn't it? Banking, travel, excitement, adventure, thrills, decisions affecting people's lives.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Jolly good, well, er, shall I put you in touch with a bank?

speaker: Anchovy
text: Yes.

speaker: Counsellor
text: Fine.

speaker: Anchovy
text: Er... no, no, no. Look, er, it's a big decision, I'd like a couple of weeks to think about it... er... you know, don't want to jump into it too quickly. Maybe three weeks. I could let you know definitely then, I just don't want to make this definite decision. I'm er...

speaker: Counsellor
text: Well this is just one of the all too many cases on our books of chartered accountancy. The only way that we can fight this terrible debilitating social disease, is by informing the general public of its consequences, by showing young people that it's just not worth it. So, so please... give generously... to this address: The League for Fighting Chartered Accountancy, 55 Lincoln House, Basil Street, London, SW3.

speaker: Voice Over
text: There is an epic quality about the sea which has throughout history stirred the hearts and minds of Englishmen of all nations. Sir Francis Drake, Captain Webb, Nelson of Trafalgar and Scott of the Antartic - all rose to the challenge of the mighty ocean. And today another Englishman may add his name to the golden roll of history: Mr Ron Obvious of Neaps End. For today, Ron Obvious hopes to be the first man to jump the Channel.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Ron, now let's just get this quite clear - you're intending to jump across the English Channel?

speaker: Ron
text: Oh yes, that is correct, yes.

speaker: Interviewer
text: And, er, just how far is that?

speaker: Ron
text: Oh, well it's twenty-six miles from here to Calais.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Er, that's to the beach at Calais?

speaker: Ron
text: Well, no, no, provided I get a good lift off and maybe a gust of breeze over the French coast, I shall be jumping into the centre of Calais itself.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Ron are you using any special techniques to jump this great distance?

speaker: Ron
text: Oh no, no. I shall be using an ordinary two-footed jump, er, straight up in the air and across the Channel.

speaker: Interviewer
text: I see. Er, Ron, what is the furthest distance that you've jumped, er, so far?

speaker: Ron
text: Er, oh, eleven foot six inches at Motspur Park on July 22nd. Er, but I have done nearly twelve feet unofficially.

speaker: Interviewer
text: I see. Er, Ron, Ron, Ron, aren't you worried Ron, aren't you worried jumping twenty-six miles across the sea?

speaker: Ron
text: Oh, well no, no, no, no. It is in fact easier to jump over sea than over dry land.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Well how is that?

speaker: Ron
text: Er, well my manager explained it to me. You see if you're five miles out over the English Channel, with nothing but sea underneath you, er, there is a very great impetus to say in the air.

speaker: Interviewer
text: I see. Well, er, thank you very much Ron and the very best of luck.

speaker: Ron
text: Thank you. Thank you.

speaker: Interviewer
text: The man behind Ron's cross-Channel jump is his manager Mr Luigi Vercotti. Mr Vercotti, er Mr Vercotti ... Mr Vercotti...

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: What? I don't know what you're talking about.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Er, no, we're from the BBC, Mr Vercotti.

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Who?

speaker: Interviewer
text: The BBC.

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Oh, oh. I see. I thought, I thought you were the er . .. I like the police a lot, I've got a lot of time for them.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Mr, er, Mr Vercotti, what is your chief task as Ron's manager?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Well my main task is, er, to fix a sponsor for the big jump.

speaker: Interviewer
text: And who is the sponsor?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: The Chippenham Brick Company. Ah, they, er, pay all the bills, er, in return for which Ron will be carrying half a hundredweight of their bricks.

speaker: Interviewer
text: I see. Well, er, it looks as if Ron is ready now. He's got the bricks. He's had his passport checked and he's all set to go. And he's off on the first ever cross-Channel jump. Will Ron be trying the cross-Channel jump again soon?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: No. No. I'm taking him off the jumps. Er, because I've got something lined up for Ron next week that I think is very much more up his street.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Er, what's that?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Er, Ron is going to eat Chichester Cathedral.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Well, there he goes, Ron Obvious of Neaps End, in an attempt which could make him the first man ever to eat an entire Anglican Cathedral.

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Well, er, I think, David, this is something which Ron and myself are really keen on. Ron is going to tunnel from Godalming here to Java here.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Java.

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Yeah, er, I, I personally think this is going to make Ron a household name overnight.

speaker: Interviewer
text: And how far has he got?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Er, well, he's quite far now, Dave, well on the way. Well on the way, yeah.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Well where is he exactly?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Yeah.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Where?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Oh, er, well, er, you know, it's difficult to say exactly. He's er, you know, in the area of er, Ron, how far have you got?

speaker: Ron
text: Oh about two foot six Mr Vercotti.

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Yeah well keep digging lad, keep digging.

speaker: Ron
text: Mr Vercotti are you sure there isn't a spade?

speaker: Interviewer
text: Er, Mr Verccotti, what do you say to people who accuse you of exploiting Ron for your own purposes?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: Well, it's totally untrue, David. Ever since I left Sicily I've been trying to do the best for Ron. I know what Ron wants to do, I believe in him and I'm just trying to create the opportunities for Ron to do the kind of things he wants to do.

speaker: Interviewer
text: And what's he going to do today?

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: He's going to split a railway carriage with his nose.

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: The only difficult bit for Ron is getting out of the Earth's atmosphere. Er, once he's in orbit he'll be able to run straight to Mercury.

speaker: Mr Vercotti
text: I am now extremely hopeful that Ron will break the world record for remaining underground. He's a wonderful boy this, he's got this really enormous talent, this really huge talent.

speaker: First Lady
text: Oh that was a bit sad, wasn't it?

speaker: Second Lady
text: Shh. It's satire.

speaker: First Lady
text: No it isn't. This is zany madcap humour.

speaker: Second Lady
text: Oh is it?

speaker: Man
text: Good morning, I'd like to buy a cat.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Certainly sir. I've got a lovely terrier.

speaker: Man
text: No, I want a cat really.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Oh yeah, how about that?

speaker: Man
text: No, that's the terrier.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Well, it's as near as dammit.

speaker: Man
text: Well what do you mean? I want a cat.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Listen, tell you what. I'll file its legs down a bit, take its snout out, stick a few wires through its cheeks. There you are, a lovely pussy cat.

speaker: Man
text: Its not a proper cat.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Man
text: Well it wouldn't meow.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Well it would howl a bit.

speaker: Man
text: No, no, no, no. Er, have you got a parrot?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: No, I'm afraid not actually guv, we're fresh out of parrots. I'll tell you what though ... I'll lop its back legs off, make good, strip the fur, stick a couple of wings on and staple on a beak of your own choice. No problem. Lovely parrot.

speaker: Man
text: How long would that take?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Oh, let me see ... er, stripping the fur off, no legs ... Harry ... can you do a parrot job on this terrier straight away?

speaker: Harry
text: No, I'm still putting a tuck in the Airedale, and then I got the frogs to let out.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Friday?

speaker: Man
text: No I need it for tomorrow. It's a present.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Oh dear, it's a long job. You see parrot conversion ... Tell you what though, for free, terriers make lovely fish. I mean I could do that for you straight away. Legs off, fins on, stick a little pipe through the back of its neck so it can breathe, bit of gold paint, make good ...

speaker: Man
text: You'd need a very big tank.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: It's a great conversation piece.

speaker: Man
text: Yes, all right, all right ... but, uh, only if I can watch.

speaker: Pearson
text: Oh, I thought that was a bit predictable.

speaker: Man
text: It's been done before

speaker: Roman Centurion
text: Yeah, we did it for Caesar's Christmas Show.

speaker: Caesar
text: No you didn't, you did Jack and the Beanstalk.

speaker: Vicar
text: Here what was that picture?

speaker: Chairman
text: Ssh! Next! Good morning - Mr Phipps?

speaker: Gorilla
text: That's right, yes.

speaker: Chairman
text: Er, do take a seat.

speaker: Gorilla
text: Right sir.

speaker: Chairman
text: Now could you tell us roughly why you want to become a librarian?

speaker: Gorilla
text: Er, well, I've had a certain amount of experience running a library at school.

speaker: Chairman
text: Yes, yes. What sort of experience?

speaker: Gorilla
text: Er, well for a time I ran the Upper Science Library.

speaker: Chairman
text: Yes, yes. Now Mr Phipps, you do realize that the post of librarian carries with it certain very important responsibilities. I mean, there's the selection of books, the record library, and the art gallery. Now it seems to me that your greatest disadvantage is your lack of professional experience ... coupled with the fact that, uh, being a gorilla, you would tend to frighten people.

speaker: Vicar
text: Is he a gorilla?

speaker: Chairman
text: Yes he is.

speaker: Vicar
text: Well why didn't it say on his form that he's a gorilla?

speaker: Chairman
text: Well, you see applicants are not required to fill in their species.

speaker: Vicar
text: What was that picture?

speaker: Chairman
text: Sh! ... Mr Phipps, what is your attitude toward censorship in a public library?

speaker: Gorilla
text: How do you mean, sir?

speaker: Vicar
text: Well I mean for instance, would you for instance stock 'Last Exit to Brooklyn'... or ... 'Groupie'?

speaker: Gorilla
text: Yes, I think so.

speaker: Vicar
text: Good.

speaker: Chairman
text: Yes, well, that seems to me to be very sensible Mr Phipps. I can't pretend that this library hasn't had its difficulties ... Mr Robertson, your predecessor, an excellent librarian, savaged three people last week and had to be destroyed.

speaker: Gorilla
text: I'm sorry sir.

speaker: Chairman
text: Oh, no, don't be sorry. You see, I don't believe that libraries should be drab places where people sit in silence, and that's been the main reason for our policy of employing wild animals as librarians.

speaker: Vicar
text: And also, they're much more permissive. Pumas keep Hank Janson on open shelves...

speaker: Chairman
text: Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes, yes Mr Phipps. I love seeing the customers when they come in to complain about some book being damaged, and ask to see the chief librarian and then ... you should see their faces when the proud beast leaps from his tiny office, snatches the book from their hands and sinks his fangs into their soft er ... Mr Phipps ... Kong! You can be our next librarian - you're proud, majestic and fierce enough ... will you do it?

speaker: Gorilla
text: I ... don't think I can sir.

speaker: Vicar
text: Why not?

speaker: Gorilla
text: I.. I'm not really a gorilla.

speaker: Vicar
text: Eh?

speaker: Gorilla
text: I'm a librarian in a skin.

speaker: Chairman
text: Why this deception?

speaker: Gorilla
text: Well, they said it was the best way to get the job.

speaker: Chairman
text: Get out, Mr Librarian Phipps, seeing as you're not a gorilla, but only dressed up as one, trying to deceive us in order to further your career ... Next. Ah. Mr Pattinson ... Sit!

speaker: Voice Over
text: Dear Mirror View, I would like to be paid five guineas for saying something stupid about a television show. Yours sincerely, Mrs Sybil Agro.

text: Dear David Jacobs, East Grinstead, Friday. Why should I have to pay sixty-four guineas each year for my television licence when I can buy one for six. Yours sincerely, Captain R. H. Pretty. PS Support Rhodesia, cut motor taxes, save the Argylls, running-in please pass.

text: Vera ... Vera ... darling! Wake up my little lemon. Come to my arms.

text: Maurice! What are you doing here?

text: I could not keep away from you. I must have you all the time.

text: Oh nothing, dear. Just a trick of the light.

speaker: Husband
text: Righto.

speaker: Vera

text: Now then my little banana, my little fruit salad, I can wait for you no longer. You must be mine utterly...

text: Oh, Maurice!

speaker: Vera
text: Roger!

text: What's the meaning of this?

text: Oh I can explain everything, my darling!

text: This is Maurice Zatapathique ... Roger Thompson ... Roger Thompsnn ... Maurice Zatapathique.

speaker: Maurice
text: How do you do.

speaker: Roger
text: How do you do ... How could you do this to me, Vera ... after all we've been through? Dammit, I love you.

speaker: Maurice
text: Vera! Don't you understand, it's me that loves you.

speaker: Husband
text: What's happening, Vera?

speaker: Vera
text: Oh, nothing dear. Just a twig brushing against the window.

speaker: Husband
text: Righto.

text: Come to me Vera!

text: Oh ... not now, Roger.

text: Vera, my little hedgehog! Don't turn me away!

speaker: Vera
text: Oh it cannot be, Maurice.

text: Hands off, you filthy bally froggie!

text: Oh Ken, Ken Biggles!

text: Yes, Algy's here as well.

text: Algy Braithwaite?

text: (Ian Davidson) That's right... Vera ... Oh God you know we both still bally love you.

speaker: Vera

The A23s through Purleys down on the main roads near Purbrights avoiding Leatherheads and then taking the A231s entering Rottingdeans from the North. From Rottingdeans we go through Africa to Nairobis. We take the South road out of Nairobis for about twelve miles and then ask.

So I spent five ghastly years at the Hairdressers' Training Centre at Totnes. Can you imagine what it's like cutting the for years? I didn't want to be a barber anyway. I wanted to be a lumberjack. Leaping from tree to tree as they float down the mighty rivers of British Columbia . . . The giant redwood, the larch, the fir, the mighty scots pine. The smell of fresh-cut timber! You know, once in a while it is my pleasure, and my privilege, to welcome here at the Refreshment Room, some of the truly great international artists of our time. And tonight we have one such artist. Ladies and gentlemen, someone whom I've always personally admired, perhaps more deeply, more strongly, more abjectly than ever before. A man, well more than a man, a god , a great god, whose personality is so totally and utterly wonderful my feeble words of welcome sound wretchedly and pathetically inadequate. Someone whose boots I would gladly lick clean until holes wore through my tongue, a man who is so totally and utterly wonderful, that I would rather be sealed in a pit of my own filth, than dare tread on the same stage with him.Ladies and gentlemen, the incomparably superior human being, Harry Fink!
