speaker: Colonel
text: Now, I've noticed a tendency for this programme to get rather silly. Now I do my best to keep things moving along, but I'm not having things getting silly. Those two last sketches I did got very silly indeed, and that last one about the bed was even sillier. Now, nobody likes a good laugh more than I do...except perhaps my wife and some of her friends...oh yes and Captain Johnston. Come to think of it most people likes a good laugh more than I do. But that's beside the point. Now, let's have a good clean healthy outdoor sketch. Get some air into your lungs. Ten, nine, eight and all that.

speaker: First Hermit
text: Hello, are you a hermit by any chance?

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Yes that's right. Are you a hermit?

speaker: First Hermit
text: Yes, I certainly am.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Well I never. What are you getting away from?

speaker: First Hermit
text: Oh you know, the usual - people, chat, gossip, you know.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Oh I certainly do - it was the same with me. I mean there comes a time when you realize there's no good frittering your life away in idleness and trivial chit-chat. Where's your cave?

speaker: First Hermit
text: Oh, up the goat track, first on the left.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Oh they're very nice up there, aren't they?

speaker: First Hermit
text: Yes they are, I've got a beauty.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: A bit drafty though, aren't they?

speaker: First Hermit
text: No, we've had ours insulated.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Oh yes.

speaker: First Hermit
text: Yes, I used birds' nests, moss and oak leaves round the outside.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Oh, sounds marvellous.

speaker: First Hermit
text: Oh it's a treat, it really is, 'cos otherwise those stone caves can be so grim.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Yes they really can be, can't they? They really can.

speaker: First Hermit
text: Oh yes.

speaker: Third Hermit
text: Morning Frank.

speaker: Second Hermit

speaker: First Hermit
text: With the, er, green loin cloth?

text: Er no, that's Mr Seagrave. Mr Robinson's the hermit who lodges with Mr Seagrave.

speaker: First Hermit
text: Oh I see, yes.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Yes well he's put me onto wattles.

speaker: First Hermit
text: Really?

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Yes. Swears by them. Yes.

speaker: Fourth Hermit
text: Morning Frank.

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Morning Lionel. Well he says that moss tends to fall off the cave walls during cold weather. You know you might get a really bad spell and half the moss drops off the cave wall, leaving you cold.

speaker: First Hermit
text: Oh well, Mr Robinson's cave's never been exactly nirvana has it?

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Well, quite, that's what I mean. Anyway, Mr Rogers, he's the, er, hermit...

speaker: First Hermit
text: ... on the end.

text: . .. up at the top, yes. Well he tried wattles and he came out in a rash.

text: Really?

text: Yes, and there's me with half a wall wattled, I mean what'll I do?

speaker: First Hermit
text: Well why don't you try birds nests like I've done? Or else, dead bracken.

text: Frank!

speaker: Second Hermit
text: Yes Han.

text: Er, yes that'll be all right. Oh leave me a pint for breakfast will you? ... You see, you know that is the trouble with living half way up a cliff - you feel so cut off. You know it takes me two hours every morning to get out onto the moors, collect my berries, chastise myself, and two hours back in the evening.

text: Still there's one thing about being a hermit, at least you meet people.

speaker: First Hermit

speaker: Praline
text: Hello, I wish to register a complaint...Hello? Miss?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: What do you mean, miss?

speaker: Praline
text: Oh I'm sorry, I have a cold. I wish to make a complaint!

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Sorry, we're closing for lunch.

speaker: Praline
text: Never mind that, my lad. I wish to complain about this parrot what I purchased not half an hour ago from this very boutique.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Oh yes, the, the Norwegian Blue. What's wrong with it?

speaker: Praline
text: I'll tell you what's wrong with it, my lad. It's dead, that's what's wrong with it!

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: No, no, it's resting, look!

speaker: Praline
text: Look my lad, I know a dead parrot when I see one, and I'm looking at one right now.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: No no sir. it's not dead. It's resting!

speaker: Praline
text: Resting?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Yeah, remarkable bird, the Norwegian Blue, beautiful plumage, innit?

speaker: Praline
text: The plumage don't enter into it - it's stone dead.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: No, no - it's just resting!

speaker: Praline
text: All right then, if it's restin', I'll wake him up! Hello Polly! I've got a nice cuttlefish for you when you wake up, Polly Parrot!

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: There, it moved!

speaker: Praline
text: No, he didn't. That was you pushing the cage!

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: I did not.

speaker: Praline
text: Yes, you did! Hello Polly, Polly Polly Parrot, wake up. Polly. Now that's what I call a dead parrot.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: No, no. It's stunned.

speaker: Praline
text: Look my lad, I've had just about enough of this. That parrot is definitely deceased. And when I bought it not half an hour ago, you assured me that its lack of movement was due to it being tired and shagged out after a long squawk.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: It's probably pining for the fjords.

speaker: Praline
text: Pining for the fjords, what kind of talk is that? Look, why did it fall flat on its back the moment I got it home?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: The Norwegian Blue prefers kipping on it's back! Beautiful bird, lovely plumage!

speaker: Praline
text: Look, I took the liberty of examining that parrot, and I discovered the only reason that it had been sitting on its perch in the first place was that it had been nailed there.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Well of course it was nailed there. Otherwise it would muscle up to those bars and voom.

speaker: Praline
text: Look matey this parrot wouldn't voom if you put four thousand volts through it! It's bleedin' demised!

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: It's not, it's pining!

speaker: Praline
text: It's not pining, it's passed on. This parrot is no more! It has ceased to be. It's expired and gone to meet its maker.This is a late parrot. It's a stiff. Bereft of life, it rests in peace. If you hadn't nailed it to the perch it would be pushing up the daisies. It's rung down the curtain and joined the choir invisible. This is an ex-parrot.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Well, I'd better replace it, then.

speaker: Praline
text: If you want to get anything done in this country you've got to complain till you're blue in the mouth.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Sorry guv, we're right out of parrots.

speaker: Praline
text: I see. I see. I get the picture.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: I got a slug.

speaker: Praline
text: Does it talk?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Not really, no.

speaker: Praline
text: Well, it's scarcely a replacement, then is it?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Listen, I'll tell you what, tell you what, if you go to my brother's pet shop in Bolton he'll replace your parrot for you.

speaker: Praline
text: Bolton eh?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Yeah.

speaker: Praline
text: All right.

text: Er, excuse me. This is Bolton, is it?

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: No, no it's, er, Ipswich.

text: That's Inter-City Rail for you.

speaker: Praline
text: I wish to make a complaint.

text: I don't have to do this, you know.

speaker: Praline
text: I beg your pardon.

text: I'm a qualified brain surgeon. I only do this because I like being my own boss.

speaker: Praline
text: Er, excuse me, this is irrelevant, isn't it.

speaker: Praline
text: Well I wish to make a complaint. I got on the Bolton train and found myself deposited here in Ipswich.

speaker: Porter
text: No, this is Bolton.

speaker: Praline
text: The pet shop owner's brother was lying.

speaker: Porter
text: Well you can't blame British Rail for that.

speaker: Praline
text: If this is Bolton, I shall return to the pet shop.

speaker: Praline
text: I understand that this Bolton.

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Yes.

speaker: Praline

speaker: Shopkeeper

speaker: Praline

speaker: Shopkeeper

speaker: Praline

speaker: Shopkeeper
text: Yes, yes.

speaker: Praline
text: It's not a palindrome. The palindrome of Bolton would be Notlob. It don't work.

speaker: Shopkeeper

speaker: Praline

speaker: Voice Over
text: This is a frightened city. Over these houses, over these streets hangs a pall of fear. Fear of a new kind of violence which is terrorizing the city. Yes, gangs of old ladies attacking defenseless, fit young men.

speaker: First Young Man
text: Well they come up to you, like, and push you - shove you off the pavement, like. There's usually four or five of them.

speaker: Second Young Man
text: Yeah, this used to be a nice neighbourhood before the old ladies started moving in. Nowadays some of us daren't even go down to the shops.

speaker: Third Young Man
text: Well Mr Johnson's son Kevin, he don't go out any more. He comes back from wrestling and locks himself in his room.

speaker: Voice Over
text: What are they in it for, these old hoodlums, these layabouts in lace?

speaker: First Granny
text: Well it's something to do isn't it?

speaker: Second Granny
text: It's good fun.

speaker: Third Granny
text: It's like you know, well, innit, eh?

speaker: Voice Over
text: Favourite targets for the old ladies are telephone kiosks.

speaker: Policeman
text: Well come on, come on, off with you. Clear out, come on get out of it. We have a lot of trouble with these oldies. Pension day's the worst - they go mad. As soon as they get their hands on their money they blow it all on milk, bread, tea, tin of meat for the cat.

speaker: Cinema Manager
text: Yes, well of course they come here for the two o'clock matinee, all the old bags out in there, especially if it's something like 'The Sound of Music'. We get seats ripped up, hearing aids broken, all that sort of thing.

speaker: Reporter
text: The whole problem of these senile delinquents lies in their complete rejection of the values of contemporary society. They've seen their children grow up and become accountants, stockbrokers and even sociologists, and they begin to wonder if it is all really... arggh!

speaker: Fourth Young Man
text: Oh well we sometimes feel we're to blame in some way for what our gran's become. I mean she used to be happy here until she, she started on the crochet.

speaker: Reporter
text: Crochet?

speaker: Fourth Young Man
text: Yeah. Now she can't do without it. Twenty balls of wool a day, sometimes. If she can't get the wool she gets violent. What can we do about it?

speaker: Voice Over
text: But this is not just an old ladies' town. There are other equally dangerous gangs - such as the baby snatchers.

speaker: Wife
text: (Rita Davies) I just left my husband out here while I went in to do some shopping and I came back and he was gone. He was only forty-seven.

speaker: Voice Over
text: And on the road too, vicious gangs of keep left signs.

speaker: Colonel
text: Right, right, stop it. This film's got silly. Started off with a nice little idea about grannies attacking young men, but now it's got silly. This man's hair is too long for a vicar too. These signs are pretty badly made. Right, now for a complete change of mood.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Good evening. Tonight we're going to take a hard tough abrasive look at camel spotting. Hello.

speaker: Spotter
text: Hello Peter.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Now tell me, what exactly are you doing?

speaker: Spotter
text: Er well, I'm camel spotting. I'm spotting to see if there are any camels that I can spot, and put them down in my camel spotting book.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Good. And how many camels have you spotted so far?

speaker: Spotter
text: Oh, well so far Peter, up to the present moment, I've spotted nearly, ooh, nearly one.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Nearly one?

speaker: Spotter
text: Er, call it none.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Fine. And er how long have you been here?

speaker: Spotter
text: Three years.

speaker: Interviewer
text: So, in, er, three years you've spotted no camels?

speaker: Spotter
text: Yes in only three years. Er, I tell a lie, four, be fair, five. I've been camel spotting for just the seven years. Before that of course I was a Yeti spotter.

speaker: Interviewer
text: A Yeti spotter, that must have been extremely interesting.

speaker: Spotter
text: Oh, it was extremely interesting, very, very - quite... it was dull; dull, dull, dull, oh God it was dull. Sitting in the Waterloo waiting room. Course once you've seen one Yeti you've seen them all.

speaker: Interviewer
text: And have you seen them all?

speaker: Spotter
text: Well I've seen one. Well a little one... a picture of a... I've heard about them.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Well, now tell me, what do you do when you spot a camel?

speaker: Spotter
text: Er, I take its number.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Camels don't have numbers.

speaker: Spotter
text: Ah, well you've got to know where to look. Er, they're on the side of the engine above the piston box.

speaker: Interviewer
text: What?

speaker: Spotter
text: Ah - of course you've got to make sure it's not a dromedary. 'Cos if it's a dromedary it goes in the dromedary book.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Well how do you tell if it's a dromedary?

speaker: Spotter
text: Ah well, a dromedary has one hump and a camel has a refreshment car, buffet, and ticket collector.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Mr Sopwith, aren't you in fact a train spotter?

speaker: Spotter
text: What?

speaker: Interviewer
text: Don't you in fact spot trains?

speaker: Spotter
text: Oh, you're no fun anymore.

speaker: Girl
text: (Donna Reading) Oh, you're no fun anymore.

speaker: Lasher
text: .. thirty-nine... forty. All right, cut him down, Mr Fuller.

speaker: Lashee
text: Oh you're no fun anymore.

speaker: Spotter

speaker: Interviewer

speaker: Accountant
text: Lady Chairman, sir, shareholders, ladies and gentlemen. I have great pleasure in announcing that owing to a cutback on surplus expenditure of twelve million Canadian dollars, plus a refund of seven and a half million Deutschmarks from the Swiss branch, and in addition adding the debenture preference stock of the three and three quarter million to the directors' reserve currency account of seven and a half million, plus an upward expenditure margin of eleven and a half thousand lira, due to a rise in capital investment of ten million pounds, this firm last year made a complete profit of a shilling.

speaker: Chairman
text: A shilling Wilkins?

speaker: Accountant
text: Er, roughly, yes sir.

speaker: Chairman
text: Wilkins, I am the Chairman of a multi-million pound corporation and you are a very new chartered Accountant. Isn't it possible there may have been some mistake?

speaker: Chairman

speaker: Accountant

speaker: Board Member
text: Five pence of a sixpence?

speaker: Accountant
text: Yes sir.

speaker: Chairman
text: Five pence of a further ?

speaker: Accountant
text: That's right sir.

speaker: Chairman
text: Then where is the other penny?

text: That makes you a penny short Wilkins. Where is it?

speaker: Accountant
text: ... Erm.

speaker: Chairman
text: Wilkins?

speaker: Accountant
text: I embezzled it sir.

speaker: Chairman
text: What all of it?

speaker: Accountant
text: Yes all of it.

speaker: Board Member
text: You naughty person.

speaker: Accountant
text: It's my first. Please be gentle with me.

speaker: Chairman
text: I'm afraid it's my unpleasant duty to inform you that you're fired.

speaker: Accountant
text: Oh please, please.

speaker: Chairman
text: No, out!

speaker: Accountant
text: Oh ...

speaker: American Voice
text: The Universe consists of a billion, billion galaxies... 77,000,000,000 miles across, and every galaxy is made up of a billion, zillion stars and around these stars circle a billion planets, and of all of these planets the greenest and the pleasantest is the planet Earth, in the system of Sol, in the Galaxy known as the Milky Way ... And it was to this world that creatures of an alien planet came ... to conquer and destroy the very heart of civilization...

speaker: American Voice
text: It was a day like any other and Mr and Mrs Samuel Brainsample were a perfectly ordinary couple, leading perfectly ordinary lives - the sort of people to whom nothing extraordinary ever happened, and not the kind of people to be the centre of one of the most astounding incidents in the history of mankind ... So let's forget about them and follow instead the destiny of this man ... ... Harold Potter, gardener, and tax official, first victim of Creatures from another Planet.

speaker: Newsvendor's Voice
text: Read all abaht it! Read all abaht it! Man turns into Scotsman!

speaker: Inspector
text: Mrs Potter - you knew Harold Potter quite well I believe?

speaker: Wife
text: Oh yes quite well.

speaker: Inspector
text: Yes.

speaker: Wife
text: He was my husband.

speaker: Inspector
text: Yes. And, er, he never showed any inclination towards being a Scotsman before this happened?

speaker: Wife
text: No, no, not at all. He was not that sort of person...

speaker: Inspector
text: He didn't wear a kilt or play the bagpipes?

speaker: Wife
text: No, no.

speaker: Inspector
text: He never got drunk at night or bought home black puddings?

speaker: Wife
text: No, no. Not at all.

speaker: Inspector
text: He didn't have an inadequate brain capacity?

speaker: Wife
text: No, no, not at all.

speaker: Inspector
text: I see. So by your account Harold Potter was a perfectly ordinary Englishman without any tendency towards being a Scotsman whatsoever?

speaker: Wife
text: Absolutely, yes. Mind you he did always watch Dr Finlay on television.

speaker: Inspector
text: Ah-hah! ... Well that's it, you see. That's how it starts.

speaker: Wife
text: I beg your pardon?

speaker: Inspector
text: Well you see Scottishness starts with little things like that, and works up. You see, people don't just turn into a Scotsman for no reason at all... No further questions!

speaker: She
text: (Donna Reading) Charles...

speaker: Charles
text: Darling...

speaker: She
text: Charles...

speaker: Charles
text: Darling, darling...

speaker: She
text: Charles... there's something I've got to tell you...

speaker: Charles
text: What is it darling?

speaker: She
text: It's daddy ... he's turned into a Scotsman...

speaker: Charles
text: What! Mr Llewellyn?

speaker: She
text: Yes, Charles. Help me, please help me.

speaker: Charles
text: But what can I do?

speaker: She
text: Surely, Charles, you're the Chief Scientist at the Anthropological Research Institute, at Butley Down - an expert in what makes people change from one nationality to another.

speaker: Charles
text: So I am! This is right up my street!

speaker: She
text: Oh good.

speaker: Charles
text: Now first of all, why would anyone turn into a Scotsman?

speaker: She
text: Em, for business reasons?

speaker: Charles
text: No, no! Only because he has no control over his own destiny! Look I'll show you...

speaker: She
text: I see.

speaker: Charles
text: Yes! So this means that some person or persons unknown is turning all these people into Scotsmen...

speaker: She
text: Oh, what kind of heartless fiend could that to a man?

speaker: Charles
text: I don't know ... I don't know ... all I know is that these people are streaming north of the border at the rate of thousands every hour. If we don't act fast, Scotland will be choked with Scotsmen...

speaker: She
text: Ooh!...

speaker: American Voice
text: Soon Scotland was full of Scotsmen. The over-crowding was pitiful.

speaker: American Voice
text: Three men to a caber.

speaker: American Voice
text: For the few who remained, life was increasingly difficult.

speaker: She
text: Charles! Thank goodness I've found you! It's mummy!

speaker: Charles
text: Hello mummy.

speaker: She
text: No, no, mummy's turned into a Scotsman...

speaker: Charles
text: Oh how horrible... Will they stop at nothing?

speaker: She
text: I don't know - do you think they will?

speaker: Charles
text: I meant that rhetorically.

speaker: She
text: What does rhetorically mean?

speaker: Charles
text: It means, I didn't expect an answer.

speaker: She
text: Oh I see. Oh, you're so clever, Charles.

speaker: Charles
text: Did mummy say anything as she changed?

speaker: She
text: Yes! she did, now you come to mention it

speaker: Charles
text: Well, what was it?

speaker: She
text: Oh, she said ... 'Them!' Is there someone at the door?

speaker: Charles
text: No ... It's just the incidental music for this scene.

speaker: She
text: Oh I see...

speaker: Charles
text: 'Them' ... Wait a minute!

speaker: She
text: A minute?

speaker: Charles
text: No, I meant that metaphorically ... 'Them' ... 'Them' ... She was obviously referring to the people who turned her into a Scotsman. If only we knew who 'They' were ... And why 'They' were doing it... Who are 'Them'?

speaker: American Voice
text: Then suddenly a clue turned up in Scotland. Mr Angus Podgorny, owner of a Dunbar menswear shop, received an order for 48,000,000 kilts from the planet Skyron in the Galaxy of Andromeda.

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Angus how are y'going to get 48,000,000 kilts into the van?

speaker: Angus
text: I'll have t'do it in two goes.

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: D'you not ken that the Galaxy of Andromeda is two million, two hundred thousand light years away?

speaker: Angus
text: Is that so?

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Aye ... and you've never been further than Berwick-on-Tweed...

speaker: Angus
text: Aye ... but think o' the money dear ... £18.10.0d a kilt ...that's ... £900,000,000 - and that's without sporrans!

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Aye ... I think you ought not to go, Angus.

speaker: Angus
text: Aye ... we'd be able to afford writing paper with our names on it... We'd be able to buy that extension to the toilet...

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Aye ... but he hasn't signed the order yet, has he?

speaker: Angus
text: Who?

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Ach ... the man from Andromeda.

speaker: Angus
text: Och ... well ... he wasna really a man, d'you ken ...

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Not really a man?

speaker: Angus
text: He was as strange a thing as ever I saw, or ever I hope to see, God willing. He was a strange unearthly creature - a quivering, glistening mass...

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Angus Podgorny, what y'mean?

speaker: Angus
text: He wasna so much a man as... a blancmange!

speaker: Sergeant
text: A blancmange, eh?

speaker: Girl
text: Yes, that's right. I was just having a game of doubles with Sandra and Jocasta, Alec and David...

speaker: Sergeant
text: Hang on!

speaker: Girl
text: What?

speaker: Sergeant
text: There's five.

speaker: Girl
text: What?

speaker: Sergeant
text: Five people . . . how do you play doubles with five people?

speaker: Girl
text: Ah, well ... we were...

speaker: Sergeant
text: Sounds a bit funny if you ask me ... playing doubles with five people...

speaker: Girl
text: Well we often play like that... Jocasta plays on the side receiving service...

speaker: Sergeant
text: Oh yes?

speaker: Girl
text: Yes. It helps to speed the game up and make it a lot faster, and it means Jocasta isn't left out.

speaker: Sergeant
text: Look, are you asking me to believe that the five of you was playing doubles, when on the very next court there was a blancmange playing by itself?.

speaker: Girl
text: That's right, yes.

speaker: Sergeant
text: Well answer me this then - why didn't Jocasta play the blancmange at singles, while you and Sandra and Alec and David had a proper game of doubles with four people?

speaker: Girl
text: Because Jocasta always plays with us. She's a friend of ours.

speaker: Sergeant
text: Call that friendship? Messing up a perfectly good game of doubles?

speaker: Girl
text: It's not messing it up, officer, we like to play with five.

speaker: Sergeant
text: Look it's affair if you want to play with five people ... but don't go calling it doubles. Look at Wimbledon, right? If Fred Stolle and Tony Roche played Charlie Pasarell and Cliff Drysdale and Peaches Bartcowitz... they wouldn't go calling it doubles.

speaker: Girl
text: But what about the blancmange?

speaker: Sergeant
text: That could play Ann Haydon-Jones and her husband Pip.

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Oh, a blancmange gave you an order for 48,000,000 kilts?

speaker: Angus
text: Aye!

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: And you it?

speaker: Angus
text: Aye, I did.

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Och, you're a stupid man, Angus Podgorny.

speaker: Angus
text: Oh look woman, how many kilts did we sell last year? Nine and a half, that's all. So when I get an order for 48,000,000, I believe it - you I believe it.

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Even if it's from a blancmange?

speaker: Angus
text: Och, woman, if a blancmange is prepared to come 2,200,000 light years to purchase a kilt, they must be fairly keen on kilts. So cease yer prattling woman and get sewing. This could be the biggest breakthrough in kilts since the Provost of Edinburgh sat on a spike. Mary, we'll be rich! We'll be rich!

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Oh, but Angus... he hasna given you an earnest of his good faith!

speaker: Angus
text: Ah mebbe not but he has gi' me this...

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: What is it now?

speaker: Angus
text: An entry form for the British Open Tennis Championships at Wimbledon Toon ... signed and seconded.

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Och, but Angus, ye ken full well that Scots folk dinna know how to play the tennis to save their lives.

speaker: Angus
text: Aye, but I must go though dear, I dinna want to seem ungrateful.

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Ach! Angus, I wilna let you make a fool o'yourself.

speaker: Angus
text: But I must.

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Och, no you'll not ...

speaker: Angus
text: Oh, Mary... Oh, oh, Mary! Look out! Look out!

speaker: Mrs Podgorny
text: Urrgh. It's the blancmange.

speaker: Policeman
text: Oh, now this is where Mr Podgorny could have saved his wife's life. If he'd gone to the police and told them that he'd been approached by unearthly beings from the Galaxy of Andromeda, we'd have sent a man round to investigate. As it was he did a deal with a blancmange, and the blancmange ate his wife. So if you're going out, or going on holiday, or anything strange happens involving other galaxies, just nip round to your local police station, and tell the sergeant on duty - or his wife - of your suspicions. And the same goes for dogs. So I'm sorry to have interrupted your exciting science fiction story ... but, then, crime's our business you know. So carry on viewing, and my thanks to the BBC for allowing me to have this little chat with you. Goodnight. God bless, look after yourselves.

speaker: Detective
text: Do sit down, Mr Podgorny... I... I ... think what's happened is ... terribly ... terribly... funny .... tragic. But you must understand that we have to catch the creature that ate your wife, and if you could help us answer a few questions, we may be able to help save a few lives. I know this is the way your wife would have wanted it.

speaker: Angus
text: Aye ... I'll ... do ... my best, sergeant.

speaker: Detective
text: Detective Inspector!

speaker: Angus
text: Er, detective inspector.

speaker: Detective
text: Now then. The facts are these. You received an order for 48,000,000 kilts from a blancmange from the planet Skyron in the Galaxy of Andromeda ... you'd just shown your wife an entry form for Wimbledon, which you'd filled in... when you turned round and saw her legs disappearing into a blancmange. Is that correct?

speaker: Angus
text: Yes, sir.

speaker: Detective
text: Are you mad?

speaker: Angus
text: No, sir.

speaker: Detective
text: Well that's a relief. 'Cos if you were, your story would be less plausible. Now then, do you recognize this?

speaker: Angus
text: Oh yes. That's the one that ate my Mary!

speaker: Detective
text: Good. His name's Riley... Jack Riley... He's that most rare of criminals ... a blancmange impersonator and cannibal.

speaker: Angus
text: But what about the 48,000,000 kilts and the Galaxy of Andromeda?

speaker: Detective
text: I'm afraid that's just one of his stories. You must understand that a blancmange impersonator and cannibal has to use some pretty clever stories to allay suspicion.

speaker: Angus
text: Then you mean...

speaker: Detective
text: Yes.

speaker: Angus
text: But...

speaker: Detective
text: How?

speaker: Angus
text: Yes.

speaker: Detective
text: Well...

speaker: Angus
text: Not?

speaker: Detective
text: I'm afraid so.

speaker: Angus
text: Why?

speaker: Detective
text: Who knows?

speaker: Angus
text: Do you think?

speaker: Detective
text: Could be.

speaker: Angus
text: But...

speaker: Detective
text: I know.

speaker: Angus
text: She was...

speaker: Detective
text: Yes.

speaker: Detective
text: Good lord what's that? Ah, Riley! Come to give yourself up have you, Riley? Eh Riley? Riley! Riley! It's not Riley!

speaker: Detective
text: It's an extra-terrestial being! Agggh!

speaker: Charles
text: So, everyone in England is being turned into Scotsmen, right?

speaker: She
text: Yes.

speaker: Charles
text: Now, which is the worst tennis-playing nation in the world?

speaker: She
text: Er ... Australia.

speaker: Charles
text: No. Try again.

speaker: She
text: Australia?

speaker: Charles
text: No... try again but say a different place.

speaker: She
text: Oh, I thought you meant I'd said it badly.

speaker: Charles
text: No, course you didn't say it badly. Now hurry.

speaker: She
text: Er, Czechoslovakia.

speaker: Charles
text: No! Scotland!

speaker: She
text: Of course.

speaker: Charles
text:
Now ... now these blancmanges, apart from the one that killed Mrs Podgorny
have all appeared in which London suburb?

speaker: She
text: Finchley?

speaker: Charles
text: No. Wimbledon ... Now do you begin to see the pattern? With what sport is Wimbledon commonly associated?

speaker: Norman Hackforth
text: For viewers at home, the answer is coming up on your screens. Those of you who wish to play it the hard way, stand upside down with your head in a bucket of piranha fish. Here is the question once again.

speaker: Charles
text: With what sport is Wimbledon commonly associated?

speaker: She
text: Cricket.

speaker: Charles
text: No.

speaker: She
text: Pelote?

speaker: Charles
text: No. Wimbledon is most commonly associated with tennis.

speaker: She
text: Of course! Now I see!

speaker: Charles
text: Yes, it all falls into place!

speaker: She
text: The blancmangcs are really Australians trying to get the rights of the pelota rules from the Czech publishers!

speaker: Charles
text: No ... not quite ... but, er, just look in here.

speaker: Charles
text: Yes. So these blancmanges, blancmange-shaped creatures come from the planet Skyron in the Galaxy of Andromeda. They order 48,000,000 kilts from a Scottish menswear shop ... turn the population of England into Scotsmen (well known as the worst tennis-playing nation on Earth) thus leaving England empty ! Empty during Wimbledon fortnight ... what's more the papers are full of reports of blancmanges appearing on tennis courts up and down the country - . This can only mean one thing!

speaker: Voice Over
text: 'THEY MEAN TO WIN WIMBLEDON'

speaker: Charles
text: They mean to !

speaker: Commentator
text: Well, here at Wimbledon, it's been a most extraordinary week's tennis. The blancmanges have swept the board, winning match after match. Here are just a few of the results: Billie-Jean King eaten in straight sets, Laver smothered whole after winning the first set, and Poncho Gonzales, serving as well as I've never seen him, with some superb volleys and decisive return volleys off the back hand, was sucked through the net at match point and swallowed whole in just under two minutes. And so, here on the final day, there seems to be no players left to challenge the blancmanges. And this could be their undoing, Dan: as the rules of Wimbledon state quite clearly that there must be at least one human being concerned in the final. Well the blancmange is coming out onto the pitch now, and there is a human with it. It's Angus Podgorny! The plucky little Scottish tailor ... upon whom everything depends. And so it's Podgorny versus blancmange in this first ever Intergalactic Wimbledon!

speaker: Commentator's Voice
text: And it's blancmange to serve and it's a good one.

speaker: Blancmange Umpire
text: Blurb blurble blurb.

speaker: Voice Over
text: Fifteen love.

speaker: BLANCMANGE:
text: 40 PODGORNY: 0

speaker: Commentator's Voice
text: And Podgorny fails to even hit the ball ... but this is no surprise as he hasn't hit the ball once throughout this match. So it's 72 match points to the blancmange now... Podgorny prepares to serve again.

speaker: BLANCMANGE:
text: 6 6 5 40 PODGORNY: 0 0

speaker: Commentator's Voice
text: This is indeed a grim day for the human race, Dan.

speaker: Commentator's Voice
text: But what's this? Two spectators have rushed onto the pitch with spoons and forks... what are they going to do?

speaker: Charles
text: They mean to eat the blancmange.

speaker: Commentator's Voice
text: And they're eating the blancmange ... Yes! The blancmange is leaving the court... it's abandoning the game! This is fantastic!

speaker: American Voice
text: Yes it was Mr and Mrs Samuel Brainsample, who, after only a brief and misleadling appearance in the early part of the film, returned to save the Earth ... but why?

speaker: Mr Brainsample
text: Oh, well you see we love blancmanges. My wife makes them.

speaker: American Voice
text: She makes blancmanages size?

speaker: Mr Brainsample
text: Oh, yes. You see we're from the planet Skyron in the Galaxy of Andromeda, and they're all that size there. We tried to tell you at the beginning of the film but you just panned off us.

speaker: American Voice
text: So the world was saved! And Angus Podgorny became the first Scotsman to win Wimbledon... fifteen years later.

speaker: It's Man
text: It's...

speaker: Man
text: I thought you did that so well Mr Figgis, could I have your autograph?

speaker: Figgis
text: You certainly can

speaker: Figgis
text: Beethoven, Mozart, Chopin, Liszt, Brahms, Panties...I'm sorry...Schumann, Schubert, Mendelssohn and Bach. Names that will live for ever. But there is one composer whose name is never included with the greats. Why is it that the world never remembered the name of Johann Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm? To do justice to this man, thought by many to be the greatest name in German Baroque music, we present a profile of Johann Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm. We start with an interview with his only surviving relative Karl Gambolputty de von Ausfern...

speaker: Karl
text: Oh ja. When I first met Johann Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm, he was with his wife, Sarah Gambolputty de von...

speaker: Interviewer
text: Yes, if I may just cut in on you there, Herr Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm, and ask you - just quickly - if there's any particular thing that you remember about Johann Gambolputty de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter- crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle- dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher- apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic- grander- knotty- spelltinkle- grandlich- grumblemeyer- spelterwasser- kurstlich- himbleeisen- bahnwagen- gutenabend- bitte- ein- nürnburger- bratwustle- gerspurten- mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut- gumberaber- shönedanker- kalbsfleisch- mittler- aucher von Hautkopft of Ulm?

speaker: Figgis
text: A tribute to Johann Gambolputty...

speaker: Viking
text: ...de von Ausfern- schplenden- schlitter...

speaker: Man
text: ...crasscrenbon- fried- digger- dingle- dangle- dongle...

speaker: Knight in Armour
text: ...dungle- burstein- von- knacker- thrasher...

speaker: Mona Lisa
text: ...apple- banger- horowitz- ticolensic...

speaker: Lon Chaney
text: ...grander- knotty- spelltinkle...

speaker: Policeman
text: ...grandlich...

speaker: Pig
text: ...grumblemeyer...

speaker: Policeman
text: ...spelterwasser...

speaker: Boar
text: ...kurstlich- himbleeisen...

speaker: Botticelli Lover
text: ...bahnwagen- gutenabend...

speaker: Medieval Couple
text: ...bitte- ein- nürnburger...

speaker: Family Group
text: ...bratwustle...

speaker: Doctor
text: ...gerspurten...

speaker: Bishop & Saint
text: ...mitz- weimache- luber- hundsfut...

speaker: Two Dancers
text: ...gumberaber- shönedanker...

speaker: Three Naked Ladies
text: ...kalbsfleisch...

speaker: Cricket Team
text: ...mittler- aucher...

speaker: Policemen
text: ...von Hautkopft...

speaker: Figgis
text: ...of Ulm.

speaker: Boss
text: All clear?

speaker: Fifth
text: All clear, boss.

speaker: Boss
text: Right ... this is the plan then. At 10:45 .. you, Reg, collect me and Ken in the van, and take us round to the British Jewellery Centre in the High Street. We will arrive outside the British Jewellery Centre at 10:50 a of m. I shall then get out of the car, you Reg, take it and park it back here in Denver Street, right? At 10:51, I shall enter the British Jewellery Centre, where you, Vic, disguised as a customer, will meet me and hand me £5.18.3d. At 10:52, I shall approach the counter and purchase a watch costing £5.18.3d. I shall then give the watch to you, Vic. You'll go straight to Norman's Garage in East Street. You lads continue back up here at 10:56 and we rendezvous in the back room at the Cow and Sickle, at 11:15. All right, any questions?

speaker: Larry
text: We don't seem to be doing anything illegal.

speaker: Boss
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Larry
text: Well ... we're paying for the watch.

speaker: Boss
text: Yes...

speaker: Larry
text: Well... why are we for the watch?

speaker: Boss
text: They wouldn't give it to us if we didn't for it, would they... eh?

speaker: Larry
text: Look! I don't like this outfit.

speaker: Boss
text: Why not?

speaker: Larry
text: Well, we never break the bloody law.

speaker: Boss
text: What d'you mean?

speaker: Larry
text: Well, look at that bank job last week.

speaker: Boss
text: What was wrong with that?

speaker: Larry
text: Well having to go in there with a mask on and ask for £15 out of my deposit account; that's what was wrong with it.

speaker: Boss
text: Listen! What are you trying to say, Larry?

speaker: Larry
text: Couldn't we just steal the watch, Boss

speaker: Boss
text: Oh, you dumb cluck! We spent weeks organizing this job. Reg rented a room across the road and filmed the people going in and out every day. Vic spent three weeks looking at watch catalogues...until he knew the price of each one backwards, and now I'm not going to risk the whole raid just for the sake of breaking the law.

speaker: Larry
text: Urr... couldn't we park on a double yellow line?

speaker: Boss
text: No!

speaker: Larry
text: Couldn't we get a dog to foul the foot...

speaker: Boss
text: No!

speaker: Reg
text: 'Ere, Boss!

speaker: Boss
text: What's the matter with you?

speaker: Reg
text: I just thought... I left the car on a meter... and it's...

speaker: Boss
text: Overdue?

speaker: Reg
text: Yes, Boss.

speaker: Boss
text: How much?

speaker: Reg
text: I dunno, Boss... maybe two ... maybe five minutes ...

speaker: Boss
text: Five minutes overdue. You fool! You fool! All right ... we've no time to lose. Ken - shave all your hair off, get your passport and meet me at this address in Rio de Janeiro Tuesday night. Vic - go to East Africa, have plastic surgery and meet me there. Reg - go to Canada and work your way south to Nicaragua by July. Larry - you stay here as front man. Give us fifteen minutes then blow the building up. All right, make it fast.

speaker: Larry
text: I can't blow the building up.

speaker: Boss
text: Why not?

speaker: Larry
text: It's illegal.

speaker: Boss
text: Oh bloody hell. Well we'd better give ourselves up then.

speaker: Reg
text: We can't, Boss.

speaker: Boss
text: Why not?

speaker: Reg
text: We haven't done anything illegal.

speaker: Bandit
text: No I think being illegal makes it more exciting.

speaker: Second Bandit
text: Yes, I agree. I mean, if you're going to go straight you might as well be a vicar or something.

speaker: Vicar
text: What?

speaker: Chartered Accountant
text: I agree. If there were fewer robbers there wouldn't be so many of them, numerically speaking.

speaker: Pepperpot
text: I think sexual ecstasy is over-rated.

speaker: Scotsman
text: Well, how very interesting, because I'm now made entirely of tin.

speaker: Praline
text: After a few more of these remarks, I shall be appearing in a sketch, so stay tuned.

speaker: Policeman
text: It's the uniform that puts them off, that and my bad breath.

speaker: Judge
text: We like dressing up, yes...

speaker: Inspector Praline
text: Hello again. I am at present still on film, but in a few seconds I shall be appearing in the studio. Thank you.

speaker: Praline
text: Hello. Mr Milton? You are sole proprietor and owner of the Whizzo Chocolate Company?

speaker: Milton
text: I am.

speaker: Praline
text: Superintendent Parrot and I are from the hygiene squad.We want to have a word with you about your box of chocolates entitled the Whizzo Quality Assortment.

speaker: Milton
text: Ah, yes.

speaker: Praline
text: If I may begin at the beginning. First there is the Cherry Fondue. This is extremely nasty, but we can't prosecute you for that.

speaker: Milton
text: Agreed.

speaker: Praline
text: Next we have number four, 'Crunchy Frog'.

speaker: Milton
text: An, yes.

speaker: Praline
text: Am I right in thinking there's a real frog in here?

speaker: Milton
text: Yes. A little one.

speaker: Praline
text: What sort of frog?

speaker: Milton
text: A dead frog.

speaker: Praline
text: Is it cooked?

speaker: Milton
text: No.

speaker: Praline
text: What, a raw frog?

speaker: Milton
text: We use only the finest baby frogs, dew-picked and flown from Iraq, cleansed in the finest quality spring water, lightly killed, and then sealed in a succulent Swiss quintuple smooth treble cream milk chocolate envelope, and lovingly frosted with glucose.

speaker: Praline
text: That's as may be, but it's still a frog!

speaker: Milton
text: What else?

speaker: Praline
text: Well don't you even take the bones out?

speaker: Milton
text: If we took the bones out it wouldn't be crunchy would it?

speaker: Praline
text: Superintendent Parrot ate one of those.

speaker: Parrot
text: Excuse me a moment.

speaker: Praline
text: Well, the Superintendent thought it was an almond whirl. People won't expect there to be a frog in there. They're bound to think it's some sort of mock frog.

speaker: Milton
text: Mock frog? We use no artificial preservatives or additives of any kind!

speaker: Praline
text: Nevertheless, I must warn you that in future you should delete the words 'crunchy frog', and replace them with the legend, 'crunchy raw unboned real dead frog' if you want to avoid prosecution.

speaker: Milton
text: What about our sales?

speaker: Praline
text: I'm not interested in your sales! I have to protect the general public! Now what about this one. It was number five, wasn't it? Number five Ram's Bladder Cup. What sort of confection is this?

speaker: Milton
text: We use choicest juicy chunks of fresh Cornish ram's bladder, emptied, steamed, flavoured with sesame seeds, whipped into a fondue and garnished with lark's vomit.

speaker: Praline
text: Larks vomit?

speaker: Milton
text: Correct.

speaker: Praline
text: Well it don't say nothing about that here.

speaker: Milton
text: Oh yes it does, on the bottom of the box, after monosodium glutamate.

speaker: Praline
text: Wel I hardly think this is good enough. I think it's be more appropriate if the box bore a great red label warning lark's vomit.

speaker: Milton
text: Our sales would plummet!

speaker: Praline
text:
Well why don't you move into more conventional areas of confectionary,
like praline or lime cream; a very popular flavor, I'm lead to understand. I mean look at this one 'cockroach cluster', anthrax ripple! What's this one: 'spring surprise'?

speaker: Milton
text: Ah - now, that's our speciality - covered with darkest creamy chocolate. When you pop it into your mouth steel bolts spring out and plunge straight through both cheeks.

speaker: Praline
text: Well where's the pleasure in that? If people place a nice chocky in their mouth, they don't want their cheeks pierced. In any case this is an inadequate description of the sweetmeat. I shall have to ask you to accompany me to the station.

speaker: Milton
text: It's a fair cop.

speaker: Praline
text: Stop talking to the camera.

speaker: Milton
text: I'm sorry.

speaker: Parrot
text: If only the general public would take more care when buying its sweeties, it would reduce the number of man-hours lost to the nation and they would spend less time having their stomachs pumped and sitting around in public lavatories.

speaker: Announcer
text: The BBC would like to apologize for the extremely poor quality of the next announcement, only he's not at all well.

speaker: Parrot
text: We present 'The Dull Life of a City Stockbroker',

speaker: Indian
text: Me heap want see play. Me want play start heap soon.

speaker: Man
text: Yes well. I think it ... begins in a minute.

speaker: Indian
text: Me heap big fan Cicely Courtneidge.

speaker: Man
text: Yes ... she's very good.

speaker: Indian
text: She fine actress ... she make interpretation heap subtle ... she heap good diction and timing ... she make part really live for Indian brave.

speaker: Man
text: Yes ... yes ... she's marvelous...

speaker: Indian
text: My father - Chief Running Stag - leader of mighty Redfoot tribe - him heap keen on Michael Denison and Dulcie Gray.

speaker: Man
text: Do you go to the theatre a lot?

speaker: Indian
text: When moon high over prairie ... when wolf howl over mountain, when mighty wind roar through Yellow Valley, we go Leatherhead Rep - block booking, upper circle - whole tribe get it on 3/6d each.

speaker: Man
text: That's very good.

speaker: Indian
text: Stage Manager, Stan Wilson, heap good friend Redfoot tribe. After show we go pow-wow speakum with director, Sandy Camp, in snug bar of Bell and Compasses. Him mighty fine director. Him heap famous.

speaker: Man
text: Oh - I don't know him myself.

speaker: Indian
text: Him say Leatherhead Rep like do play with Redfoot tribe.

speaker: Man
text: Oh that's good...

speaker: Indian
text: We do 'Dial M for Murder'. Chief Running Elk - him kill buffalo with bare hands, run thousand paces when the sun is high - him play Chief Inspector Hardy - heap good fine actor.

speaker: Man
text: You do a lot of acting do you?

speaker: Indian
text: Yes. Redfoot tribe live by acting and hunting.

speaker: Man
text: You don't fight any more?

speaker: Indian
text: Yes! Redfoot make war! When Chief Yellow Snake was leader, and Mighty Eagle was in land of forefather, we fight Pawnee at Oxbow Crossing. When Pawnee steal our rehearsal copies of 'Reluctant Debutante' we kill fifty Pawnee - houses heap full every night. Heap good publicity.

speaker: Man
text: I think he's about to start now, thank God for that.

speaker: Indian
text: Paleface like eat chocolate?

speaker: Man
text: No, thank you very much.

speaker: Indian
text: Hmmm - crunchy frog - heap good.

speaker: House Manager
text: Ladies and gentlemen. Before the play starts, I would like to apologize to you all, but unfortunately Miss Cicely Courtneidge is unable to appear, owing to...

speaker: Dad
text: (Ian Davidson) What's that dear?

speaker: Mum
text: There's been another Indian massacre at Dorking Civic Theatre.

speaker: Dad
text: About time too dear...

speaker: Mum
text: 'Those who were left alive at the end got their money back'.

speaker: Dad
text: That's what live theatre needs - a few more massacres...

speaker: Mum
text: 'The police are anxious to speak to anyone who saw the crime, ladies with large breasts, or just anyone who likes policemen.'

speaker: Policeman
text: Yes! Policemen make wonderful friends. So if you are over six feet tall and would like a friend, a pen friend, in the police force, here is the address to write to: 'Mrs Ena Frog, 8 Masonic Apron Street, Cowdenbeath'. Remember - policemen make wonderful friends. So write today and take advantage of our free officer. Thank you. And now for the next sketch.

speaker: Mum
text: A Scotsman on a horse.

speaker: Policeman
text: For Mrs Emma Hamilton of Nelson, a Scotsman on a horse.

speaker: Larry
text: Good morning boys.

speaker: Writers
text: Good morning Mr Saltzberg.

speaker: Larry
text: Sit down! Sit down! Sit down! Sit down! Now, boys, I want you to know that I think you are the best six writers in movies today. I want you to know that I've had an idea for the next movie I'm going to produce and I want you boys to write it.

speaker: Writers
text: Thank you. Thank you.

speaker: Larry
text: Oh sit down! Sit down! Sit down! There'll be plenty of time for that later on. Now boys, here's my idea...

speaker: Third Writer
text: It's great!

speaker: Larry
text: You like it huh?

speaker: Writers
text: Yeah, yeah, great! Really great. Fantastic.

speaker: Larry
text: Do like it?

speaker: First Writer
text: Yeah! Er ... yeah.

speaker: Larry
text: What do you like about it?

speaker: First Writer
text: Oh well you haven't told us... what it is yet...

speaker: Larry
text: WHAT!?

speaker: First Writer
text: I like what he likes.

speaker: Larry
text: What do you like?

speaker: Second Writer
text: I like what he likes.

speaker: Third Writer
text: I like what he likes.

speaker: Fourth Writer
text: I like what he likes

speaker: Fifth Writer
text: I just crazy about what he likes

speaker: Larry
text: What do you like?

speaker: Sixth Writer
text: (Ian Davidson) I ... I ... I ... agree with them.

speaker: Larry
text: Good! Now we're getting somewhere. Now, here's the start of the movie ... I see snow! White snow!

speaker: Fourth Writer
text: Think of the colours!

speaker: Larry
text: And in the snow, I see ... a tree!

speaker: Writers
text: Yes! Yes!

speaker: Larry
text: Wait, wait I haven't finished yet.

speaker: Third Writer
text: There's ?

speaker: Larry
text: And by this tree, gentlemen, I see ... a dog!

speaker: Writers
text: Olé!

speaker: Larry
text: And gentlemen, this dog goes up to the tree, and he piddles on it.

speaker: Writers
text: Hallelujah!

speaker: Sixth Writer
text: Have we got a movie!

speaker: Fifth Writer
text: He tells it the way it is!

speaker: Fourth Writer
text: It's where it's at!

speaker: Third Writer
text: This is something else!

speaker: Second Writer
text: It's out of sight!

speaker: First Writer
text: I like it, I like it.

speaker: Larry
text: Oh yeah?

speaker: First Writer
text: Yeah, yeah, I I like it

speaker: Fifth Writer
text: Sir, I don't know how to say this but I got to be perfectly frank. I really and truly believe this story of yours is the greatest story in motion-picture history.

speaker: Larry
text: Get out!

speaker: Fifth Writer
text: What?

speaker: Larry
text: If there's one thing I can't stand, it's a yes-man! Get out! I'll see you never work again. What do you think?

speaker: Sixth Writer
text: Well... I...

speaker: Larry
text: Just because I have an idea it doesn't mean it's great. It could be lousy.

speaker: Sixth Writer
text: It could?

speaker: Larry
text: Yeah! What d'ya think?

speaker: Sixth Writer
text: It's lousy.

speaker: Larry
text: There you are, you see, he spoke his mind. He said my idea was lousy. It just so happens my idea isn't lousy so get out you goddam pinko subversive, get out! You...

speaker: Fourth Writer
text: Well ... I think it's an excellent idea.

speaker: Larry
text: Are you a yes-man?

speaker: Fourth Writer
text: No, no, no, I mean there may be things against it.

speaker: Larry
text: You think it's lousy, huh?

speaker: Fourth Writer
text: No, no, I mean it takes time.

speaker: Larry
text: Are you being indecisive?

speaker: Fourth Writer
text: Yo. Nes. Perhaps.

speaker: Larry
text: I hope you three gentlemen aren't going to be indecisive! What the hell are you doing under that table?

speaker: First Writer
text: We dropped our pencils.

speaker: Larry
text: Pencil droppers, eh?

speaker: Writers
text: No, no, no, no, no!

speaker: Larry
text: Right. Now I want your opinion of my idea ... You...

speaker: First Writer
text: Oh...

speaker: Larry
text: Has he had a heart attack?

speaker: Second and Third Writers
text: Er...

speaker: Larry
text: If there's one thing I can't stand, it's people who have heart attacks.

speaker: First Writer
text: I feel fine now.

speaker: Larry
text: Well, what do you think?

speaker: Writers
text: Oh! Eh! You didn't ask me you asked him. He didn't ask me, he asked him. No, him.

speaker: Larry
text: I've changed my mind. I'm asking you, the one in the middle.

speaker: Second Writer
text: The one in the middle?

speaker: Larry
text: Yes, the one in the middle. Hello, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, Dimitri ... What the hell are you doing?

speaker: Second Writer
text: I'm thinking.

speaker: Larry
text: Get back in those seats immediately. Yes... Right you. The one in the middle, what do you think?

speaker: Second Writer
text: Er... er...

speaker: Larry
text: Come on!

speaker: Second Writer
text: Splunge.

speaker: Larry
text: Did he say splunge?

speaker: First and Third Writers
text: Yes.

speaker: Larry
text: What does splunge mean?

speaker: Second Writer
text: It means ... it's a great-idea-but-possibly-not-and-I'm-not-being-indecisive!

speaker: Larry
text: Good. Right . .. What do you think?

speaker: Third Writer
text: Er. Splunge?

speaker: Larry
text: OK...

speaker: First Writer
text: Yeah. Splunge for me too.

speaker: Larry
text: So all three of you think splunge, huh?

speaker: Writers
text: Yes!

speaker: Larry
text: Well now we're getting somewhere. No, wait. A new angle! In the snow, instead of the tree, I see Rock Hudson, and instead of the dog I see Doris Day and, gentlemen, Doris Day goes up to Rock Hudson and she kisses him. A love story. Intercourse Italian style. David Hemmings as a hippy Gestapo officer. Frontal nudity. A family picture. A comedy. And then when Doris Day's kissed Rock Hudson she says something funny like...

speaker: Third Writer
text: Er ... Good evening.

speaker: Larry
text: Doris Day's a comedienne, not a newsreader. Get out! She says something funny like

speaker: Second Writer
text: Splunge?

speaker: Larry
text: That's the stupidest idea I ever heard. Get out! Doris Dog kisses Rock Tree and she says

speaker: First Writer
text: Er... er... er... I can't take it anymore.

speaker: Larry
text: I like that! I like that, I can't take it any more, and then Rock Hudson says 'I'm a very rich film producer and I need a lobotomy' and then Doris Dog says 'I think you're very handsome and I'm going to take all my clothes off' and then Doris Dog turns into a yak and goes to the bathroom on David Lemming. No, wait, wait! Hello, hello, hello, who are you? You're an out-of-work writer? Well, you're fired. Roll the credits. Produced by Irving C. Saltzberg Jnr. of Irving C. Saltzberg Productions Ltd. and Saltzberg Art Films, Oil, Real Estate, Banking and Prostitution Inc.

speaker: It's Man
text: It's...

speaker: Voice Over
text: 'MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS'

speaker: Mr A
text: Oh good, that'll be the Vet, dear.

speaker: Mrs B
text: I'd better go and let him in.

speaker: Mrs B
text: It's the Vet, dear.

speaker: Mr A
text: Oh very glad indeed you could come round, sir.

speaker: Vet
text: Not at all. Now what seems to be the problem? You can tell me - I'm a Vet, you know.

speaker: Mrs B
text: See! Tell him, dear.

speaker: Mr A
text: Well...

speaker: Mrs B
text: It's our cat. He doesn't do anything. He just sits out there on the lawn.

speaker: Vet
text: Is he ... dead?

speaker: Mr A
text: Oh, no!

speaker: Vet
text: Thank God for that. For one ghastly moment I thought I was... too late. If only more people would call in the nick of time.

speaker: Mrs B
text: He just sits there, all day and every day.

speaker: Mr A
text: And at night.

speaker: Mrs B
text: Sh! Almost motionless. We have to take his food out to him.

speaker: Mr A
text: And his milk.

speaker: Mrs B
text: Sh! He doesn't do anything. He just sits there.

speaker: Vet
text: Are you at your wits' end?

speaker: Mrs B
text: Definitely, yes.

speaker: Vet
text: Hm. I see. Well I think I may be able to help you. You see ... ... your cat is suffering from what we Vets haven't found a word for. His condition is typified by total physical inertia, absence of interest in its ambience - what we Vets call environment - failure to respond to the conventional external stimuli - a ball of string, a nice juicy mouse, a bird. To be blunt, your cat is in a rut. It's the old stockbroker syndrome, the suburban fin de siecle ennui, angst, weltschmertz, call it what you will.

speaker: Mrs B
text: Moping.

speaker: Vet
text: In a way, in a way ... hum ... moping, I must remember that. Now, what's to be done? Tell me sir, have you confused your cat recently?

speaker: Mr A
text: Well we ...

speaker: Mrs B
text: Sh! No.

speaker: Vet
text: Yes ... well I think I can definitely say that your cat badly needs to be confused.

speaker: Mrs B
text: What?

speaker: Mr A
text: Sh! What?

speaker: Vet
text: Confused. To shake it out of its state of complacency. I'm afraid I'm not personally qualified to confuse cats, but I can recommend an extremely good service. Here is their card.

speaker: Mrs B
text: Oooh. 'Confuse-a-Cat Limited'.

speaker: Mr A
text: 'Confuse-a-Cat Limited'.'

speaker: Mrs B
text: Oh.

speaker: Sergeant
text: Squad! Eyes front! Stand at ease. Cat confusers ...shun!

speaker: General
text: Well men, we've got a pretty difficult cat to confuse today so let's get straight on with it. Jolly good. Thank you sergeant.

speaker: Sergeant
text: Confusers attend to the van and fetch out... wait for it... fetch out the funny things. Move, move, move. One, two, one, two, get those funny things off.

speaker: Sergeant
text: Stage ready for confusing, sir!

speaker: General
text: Very good. Carry on, sergeant.

speaker: Sergeant
text: Left turn, double march!

speaker: General
text: Right men, confuse the ... cat!

speaker: Long John Silver
text: My lords, ladies and Gedderbong.

speaker: General
text: I hope to God it works. Anyway, we shall know any minute now.

speaker: Mrs B
text: I can't believe it.

speaker: Mr A
text: Neither can I. It's just like the old days.

speaker: Mrs B
text: Then he's cured. Oh thank you, general.

speaker: Mr A
text: What can we ever do to repay you?

speaker: General
text: No need to, sir. It's all in a day's work for 'Confuse-a-Cat'.

speaker: Officer
text: Have you read this, sir?

speaker: Man
text: No! Oh, yes, yes - yes.

speaker: Officer
text: Anything to declare?

speaker: Man
text: Yes ... no! No! No! No! Nothing to declare, no, nothing in my suitcase no...

speaker: Officer
text: No watches, cameras, radio sets?

speaker: Man
text: Oh yes ... four watches ... no, no, no. No. One... one watch...No, no. Not even one watch. No, no watches at all. No, no watches at all. No precision watches, no.

speaker: Officer
text: Which country have you been visiting, sir?

speaker: Man
text: Switzerland ... er ... no ... no ... not Switzerland ... er ... not Switzerland, it began with S but it wasn't Switzerland... oh what could it be? Terribly bad memory for names. What's the name of that country where they don't make watches at all?

speaker: Officer
text: Spain?

speaker: Man
text: Spain! That's it. Spain, yes, mm.

speaker: Officer
text: The label says 'Zurich', sir.

speaker: Man
text: Yes well ... it Spain then.

speaker: Officer
text: Zurich's in Switzerland, sir.

speaker: Man
text: Switzerland, yes mm ... mm ... yes.

speaker: Officer
text: Switzerland - where they make the watches.

speaker: Man
text: Oh, nice shed you've got here.

speaker: Officer
text: Have you, er, got any Swiss currency, sir?

speaker: Man
text: No... just the watches... er just my watch, er, my watch on the currency... I've kept a watch on the currency, and I've watched it and I haven't got any.

speaker: Officer
text: That came out a bit glib didn't it? Have you got an alarm clock in there, sir?

speaker: Man
text: No, no, heavens no, no... just vests.

speaker: Officer
text: Sounded a bit like an alarm going off.

speaker: Man
text: Well it can't have been... it must be a vest, er, going off.

speaker: Officer
text: Going off?

speaker: Man
text: All right, I confess, I'm a smuggler ... This whole case is crammed full of Swiss watches and clocks. I've been purposely trying to deceive Her Majesty's Customs and Excise. I've been a bloody fool.

speaker: Officer
text: I don't believe you, sir.

speaker: Man
text: It's true. I'm, er, guilty of smuggling.

speaker: Officer
text: Don't give me that, sir ... you couldn't smuggle a piece of greaseproof paper let alone a case full of watches.

speaker: Man
text: What do you mean! I've smuggled watches before, you know! I've smuggled bombs, cameras, microfilms, aircraft components, you name it - I've smuggled it.

speaker: Officer
text: Now come along please, you're wasting our time... move along please.

speaker: Man
text: Look! Look - look at this.

speaker: Officer
text: Look, for all I know, sir, you could've bought these in London before you ever went to Switzerland.

speaker: Man
text: What? I wouldn't buy two thousand clocks.

speaker: Officer
text: People do, now close your case move along please come on. Don't waste our time, we're out to catch the real smugglers. Come on.

speaker: Man
text: I am a real smuggler. I'm a smuggler! Don't you understand, I'm a smuggler, a lawbreaker... a smuggler.

speaker: Vicar
text: Poor fellow. I think he needs help.

speaker: Officer
text: Right, cut the wisecracks, vicar. Get to the search room, and strip.

speaker: Chairman
text: Well to discuss the implications of that sketch and to consider the moral problems raised by the law-enforcement methods involved we have a duck, a cat and a lizard. Now first of all I'd like to put this question to you please, lizard. How effective do you consider the legal weapons employed by legal customs officers, nowadays? Well while you're thinking about that, I'd like to bring the duck in here, and ask her, if possible, to clarify the whole question of currency restrictions, and customs regulations in the world today. Perhaps the cat would rather answer that? No? Lizard? No. Well, er, let's ask the man in the street what he thinks.

speaker: French Au Pair
text: I am not a man you silly billy.

speaker: Man on Roof
text: I'm not in the street you fairy.

speaker: Man in Street
text: Well, er, speaking a man in the street... Wagh!

speaker: Man
text: What was the question again?

speaker: Voice Over
text: Just how relevant are contemporary customs regulations and currency restrictions in a modern expanding industrial economy? Oh never mind.

speaker: Pepperpot
text: Well I think customs men should be armed, so they can kill people carrying more than two hundred cigarettes.

speaker: Man
text: Well I, I think that, er, nobody who has gone abroad should be allowed back in the country. I mean, er, blimey, blimey if they're not keen enough to stay here when they're 'ere, why should we allow them back, er, at the tax-payers' expense? I mean, be fair, I mean, I don't eat squirrels do I? I mean well perhaps I do one or two but there's no law against that, is there? It's a free country. I mean if I want to eat a squirrel now and again, that's me own business, innit? I mean, I'm no racialist. I, oh, oh...

speaker: Woman
text: I think it's silly to ask a lizard what it thinks, anyway.

speaker: Chairman
text: Why?

speaker: Woman
text: I mean they should have asked Margaret Drabble.

speaker: Young Man
text: Well I think, er, customs people are quite necessary, and I think they're doing quite a good job really. Check.

speaker: Young Man
text: Door's open.

speaker: Policeman
text: Oh. Yes. All right. All right, all right, all right. My name's Police Constable Henry Thatcher, and this is a raid. I have reason to believe that there are certain substances on the premises.

speaker: Young Man
text: Well what sort of substances, officer?

speaker: Policeman
text: Er... certain substances.

speaker: Young Man
text: Well, what sort of certain substances?

speaker: Policeman
text: Er, certain substances of an illicit nature.

speaker: Young Man
text: Er, could you be more specific?

speaker: Policeman
text: I beg your pardon?

speaker: Young Man
text: Could you be 'clearer'.

speaker: Policeman
text: Oh, oh ... yes, er ... certain substances on the premises. To be removed for clinical tests.

speaker: Young Man
text: Have you got anything patiticular in mind?

speaker: Policeman
text: Well what have you got?

speaker: Young Man
text: Nothing, officer.

speaker: Policeman
text: You are Sandy Camp the actor?

speaker: Young Man
text: Yes.

speaker: Policeman
text: I must warn you, sir, that outside I have police dog Josephine, who is not only armed, and trained to sniff out certain substances, but is also a junkie.

speaker: Young Man
text: What are you after ... ?

speaker: Policeman
text: Oo! Oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh! Here is a brown paper bag I have found on the premises. I must confiscate this, sir, and take it with me for clinical examination.

speaker: Young Man
text: Wait a minute. You just got that out of your pocket.

speaker: Policeman
text: What?

speaker: Young Man
text: Well what's in it anyway? Sandwiches.

speaker: Policeman
text: Sandwiches? Blimey. Whatever did I give the wife?

speaker: Voice Over
text: Dear BBC, East Grinstead, Friday. I feel I really must write and protest about that sketch. My husband, in common with a lot of people of his age, is fifty. For how long are we to put up with these things. Yours sincerely, E. B. Debenham (Mrs).

speaker: Voice Over
text: Dear Freddy Grisewood, Bagshot, Surrey. As a prolific letter-writer, I feel I must protest about the previous letter. I am nearly sixty and am quite mad, but I do enjoy listening to the BBC Home Service. If this continues to go on unabated ...Dunkirk... dark days of the war... backs to the wall... Alvar Liddell ... Berlin air lift ... moral upheaval of Profumo case ... young hippies roaming the streets, raping, looting and killing. Yours etc., Brigadier Arthur Gormanstrop (Mrs).

speaker: Pepperpot
text: Well I think they should attack things, like that - with satire. I mean Ned Sherrin. Fair's fair. I think people should be able to make up their own minds for me.

speaker: Woman Journalist
text: Well I think they should attack the fuddy-duddy attitudes of the lower middle classes which permit the establishment to survive and keep the mores of the whole country back where they were in the nineteenth century and the ghastly days of the pre-sexual revolution.

speaker: Scotsman
text: Well that's, er, very interesting, because, er, I am, in fact, made entirely of wood.

speaker: Stockbroker
text: Well I think they should attack the lower classes, er, first with bombs, and rockets destroying their homes, and then when they run helpless into the streets, er, mowing them down with machine guns. Er, and then of course releasing the vultures. I know these views aren't popular, but I have never courted popularity.

text: I think there should be more race prejudice.

text: Less.

speaker: Boy

speaker: Man
text: Well that was all good fun, and we all had a jolly good laugh, but I would like to assure you that you'd never be treated like that if you had an interview here at the Careers Advisory Board. Perhaps I should introduce myself. I am the Head of the Careers Advisory Board. I wanted to be a doctor, but there we are, I'm Head of the Careers Advisory Board. Or a sculptor, something artistic, or an engineer, with all those dams, but there we are, it's no use crying over split milk, the facts are there and that's that. I'm the Head of this lousy Board. Never mind, now I wonder if you've ever considered what a very profitable line of work this man is in.

text: 'Allo, Marge!

text: Oh hello, Janet, how are you love?

text: Fancy seeing you! How's little Ralph?

text: Oh, don't ask me! He's been nothing but trouble all morning. Stop it Ralph! Stop it!

text: Same as my Kevin.

text:
Nothing but trouble ... leave it alone! He's just been in the Florentine Room and

text:
Well, we've just come from the Courtauld and Ralph smashed every exhibit but one

speaker: Janet
text:
Just like my Kevin. Show him an exhibition of early eighteenth-century Dresden
Pottery and he goes berserk. No, I said no, and I meant no! This morning we were viewing the early Flemish Masters of the Renaissance and Mannerist
Schools, when he gets out his black aerosol and squirts Vermeer's Lady At A Window!

text: Still it's not as bad as spitting is it?

speaker: Janet
text: No, well Kevin knows that if he spits at a painting I'll never take him to an exhibition again.

text:
Ralph used to spit - he could hit a Van Gogh at thirty yards. But he knows now it's
wrong - don't you Ralph? Ralph! Stop it! Stop it! Stop chewing that Turner!
You are ... You are a naughty, naughty, vicious little boy. Oh, look at that! The Fighting Temeraire - ruined! What
shall I do?

speaker: Janet
text: Now don't do a thing with it love, just put it in the bin over there.

text:
Yes take my word for it, Marge. Kevin's eaten most of the early nineteenth-century

myself. Yes...

text:
Flu...flu? They should eat more fresh fruit. Right. Now,

attacks you with armed with a piece of fresh fruit.

text:
Pointed sticks? Ho, ho, ho. We want to learn how to defend ourselves
against pointed sticks, do we? Getting all high and mighty, eh? Fresh
fruit not good enough for you eh? Well I'll tell you something my lad.
When you're walking home tonight and some great homicidal maniac comes
after you with a bunch of loganberries, don't come crying to me! Now,
the passion fruit. When your assailant lunges at you with a passion
fruit, thus...

Right! Bananas! How to defend yourself
against a man armed with a banana. Here, you, take this. Now, it's quite simple to defend yourself against the banana fiend. First of all, you force him to drop the banana, next, you eat the banana, thus disarming him. You have now rendered him helpless.

Come at me then...come on, do your worst, you worm. If anyone ever attacks you with a raspberry, simply pull the lever...and a sixteen-ton weight will drop on his head. I learnt that in Malaya.

text: Well that's planning, isn't it? Forethought.

text:
Look...look, smarty pants, the sixteen-ton weight is just one way of
dealing with the raspberry killer. There are millions of others!

text: Shoot him.

speaker: Second Man
text: Well, supposing you haven't got a gun or a sixteen-ton weight?

text:
All right clever dick, all right clever dick. You two, come at me
with raspberries, there you are, a whole basket each. Come on, come at me with them, then.

text: All right.

speaker: RSM
text:
Right, now don't rush me this time. I'm going to turn me back. So you can stalk me...right. Come up as quietly as you can, right, close up behind me, then, in with the raspberries, right? Start moving Now...the first thing to do when you are being stalked by an ugly mob with raspberries, is to...release the tiger. The great advantage of the tiger in unarmed combat is that it not only eats the raspberry-laden foe but also the raspberries. The tiger, however, do not relish the peach. The peach assailant should be attacked with a
crocodile. Right...I know you're there - lurking under the floorboards with your damsons and your prunes...now, the rest of you - I know you're hiding behind the wall bars with your quinces. Well I'm ready for you.
I've wired myself up to two hundred tons of gelignite, and if any one of you so
much as tries anything we'll all go up together!
I've warned you...I warned you, right. That's it...

speaker: Judge
text:
Mr Larch, you heard the case for the prosecution. Is there anything you wish to say

text:
Well... I'd just like to say, m'lud, I've got a family... a wife and six kids... and I

freedom is a state much prized within the realm of civilized society. It is a bond wherewith the savage man may charm the outward hatchments of his
soul, and soothe the troubled breast into a magnitude of quiet. It is most precious as a
blessed balm, the saviour of princes, the harbinger of happiness, yea, the very stuff and pith of
all we hold most dear. What frees the prisoner in his lonely cell, chained within the bondage
of rude walls, far from the owl of Thebes? What fires and stirs the woodcock in his springe or
wakes the drowsy apricot betides? What goddess doth the storm toss'd mariner offer her
most tempestuous prayers to? Freedom! Freedom! Freedom!

text:
I'm sorry I'm late m'lud I couldn't find a kosher car park. Er... don't bother to

text: Call Mrs Fiona Lewis.

text:
I swear to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, so anyway, I said to her, I said, they can't afford that on what he earns, I mean for a start the

know how she puts up with it after all the trouble she's had with her you-know-what, anyway
it was a white wedding much to everyone's surprise, of course they bought everything on the
hire purchase, I think they ought to send them back where they came from, I mean you've got

text: Mr Bartlett, I fail to see the relevance of your last witness.

text:

text:

text: Where is all this leading us?

text:
That will become apparent in one moment m'lud. Mr

text:

text: I think you haven't got the slightest idea what this case is about.

text:
M'lud the strange, damnable, almost diabolic threads of this extraordinary tangled

text:

speaker: Waiter
text: Good evening, sir! Good evening, madam! And may I say what a pleasure it is to see you here again, sir!

speaker: Head Waiter
text: Excuse me monsieur and madame. It's filthy, Gaston ... find out who washed this up, and give them their cards immediately.

speaker: Man
text: Oh, no, no.
