text: Better still, we can't afford to take any chances, sack the entire washing-up staff.

speaker: Man
text: No, look I don't want to make any trouble.

speaker: Head Waiter
text: Oh, no please, no trouble. It's quite right that you should point these kind of things out. Gaston, tell the manager what has happened immediately!

speaker: Man
text: Oh, no I don't want to cause any fuss.

speaker: Head Waiter
text: Please, it's no fuss. I quite simply wish to ensure that nothing interferes with your complete enjoyment of the meal.

speaker: Man
text: Oh I'm sure it won't, it was only a dirty fork.

speaker: Head Waiter
text: I know. And I'm sorry, bitterly sorry, but I know that... no apologies I can make can alter the fact that in our restaurant you have been given a dirty, filthy, smelly piece of cutlery...

speaker: Man
text: It wasn't smelly.

speaker: Head Waiter
text: It was smelly, and obscene and disgusting and I hate it, I hate it ,.. nasty, grubby, dirty, mingy, scrubby little fork. Oh ... oh . . . oh . . .

speaker: Manager
text: Good evening, sir, good evening, madam. I am the manager. I've only just heard . .. may I sit down?

speaker: Man
text: Yes, of course.

speaker: Manager
text: I want to apologize, humbly, deeply, and sincerely about the fork.

speaker: Man
text: Oh please, it's only a tiny bit... I couldn't see it.

speaker: Manager
text: Ah you're good kind fine people, for saying that, but I can see it.., to me it's like a mountain, a vast bowl of pus.

speaker: Man
text: It's not as bad as that.

speaker: Manager
text: It gets me . I can't give you any excuses for it - there are no excuses. I've been meaning to spend more time in the restaurant recently, but I haven't been too well... things aren't going very well back there. The poor cook's son has been put away again, and poor old Mrs Dalrymple who does the washing up can hardly move her poor fingers, and then there's Gilberto's war wound - but they're good people, and they're kind people, and together we were beginning to get over this dark patch ... there was light at the end of the tunnel . .. now this . .. now this...

speaker: Man
text: Can I get you some water?

speaker: Manager
text: It's the end of the road!!

speaker: Cook
text: You bastards! You vicious, heartless bastards! Look what you've done to him! He's worked his fingers to the bone to make this place what it is, and you come in with your petty feeble quibbling and you grind him into the dirt, this fine, honourable man, whose boots you are not worthy to kiss. Oh... it makes me mad... mad!

speaker: Head Waiter
text: Easy, Mungo, easy... Mungo... the war wound!... the wound... the wound...

speaker: Manager
text: This is the end! The end! Aaargh!!

speaker: Cook
text: They've destroyed him! He's dead!! They killed him!!!

speaker: Head Waiter
text: No Mungo... never kill a customer. Oh . .. the wound! The wound!

speaker: Man
text: Lucky we didn't say anything about the dirty knife.

speaker: Compère
text: Well, there we are then, that was the restaurant sketch, a nice little number...a bit vicious in parts, but a lot of fun...but how about that punch line, eh?...Oh, you know what I mean - oh...oh...really.

speaker: Newsreader
text: Good evening, here is the 6 o'clock News read by Michael Queen. It's been a quite day over most of the country as people went back to work after the warmest July weekend for nearly a year. The only high spot of the weekend was the meeting between officials of the NEDC and the ODCN in Bradford today.

speaker: Newsreader
text:
In Geneva, officials of the Central Clearing Banks met with Herr Voleschtadt of Poland to discuss non-returnable loans on a twelve-year trust basis for the construction of a new zinc-treating works in the Omsk area of Krakow, near the Bulestan border.
The Board of Trade has ratified a Trade Agreement with the Soviet Union for the sale of 600 low gear electric sewing machines. The President of the Board of Trade said he hoped this would
mark a new area of expansion in world trade and a new spirit of co-operation between East and West. There has been a substantial drop in Gold Reserves during the last twelve months. This follows a statement by the Treasury to the effect that the balance of imports situation had not changed dramatically over the same period. Still no news of the National Savings book lost by Mr Charles Griffiths of Porthcawl during a field expedition to the Nature Reserves of Swansea last July. Mr Griffiths' wife said that her husband was refusing to talk to the Press until the Savings Certificate had been found. In Cornwall the death has been announced today of the former Minister without Portfolio, General Sir Hugh Marksby-Smith. Sir Hugh was vice-president of the Rotarian movement. In the match between Glamorgan and Yorkshire, the Yorkshire bowler Nicholson took eight wickets for three runs. Glareorgan were all out for the thirty-six and therefore won the match by an innings and seven runs. Weather for tomorrow will be cloudy with occasional outbreaks of rain. And that is the end of the news.

speaker: Rustic
text:
A fair question and one that in recent weeks has been much on
my mind. It's my considered opinion that they're nesting.

speaker: City Gent
text: Nesting?

speaker: Rustic
text: Ar.

speaker: City Gent
text: Like birds?

speaker: Rustic
text:
Ar. Exactly. Birds is the key to the whole problem. It's my belief that these sheep are laborin' under the misapprehension that they're birds. Observe their behavior. Take for a start the sheeps' tendency to 'op about the field
on their back legs. Now witness their attempts to fly from tree to tree. Notice that they do not so much fly as...plummet. Observe for example that ewe in that oak tree. She is clearly trying to teach her lamb to fly. Talk about the blind leading the blind.

speaker: City Gent
text: But why do they think they're birds?

speaker: Rustic
text: Another fair question. One thing is for sure; a sheep is not a creature of the air. They have enormous difficulty in the comparatively simple act of perchin'. As you see. As for flight, its body is totally unadapted to the problems of aviation. Trouble is, sheep are very dim. Once they get an idea in their heads, there's no shifting it.

speaker: City Gent
text: But where did they get the idea from?

speaker: Rustic
text: From Harold. He's that sheep there over under the elm. He's that most dangerous of animals, a clever sheep. He's the ring-leader. He has realized that a sheep's life consists of standing around for a few months and then being eaten. And that's a depressing prospect for an ambitious sheep. He's patently hit on the idea of escape.

speaker: City Gent
text: Well why don't you just get rid of Harold?

speaker: Rustic
text: Because of the enormous commercial possibilities should he succeed.

And opposite him we have Dr Tom Jack: humanist, broadcaster, lecturer and author of the book 'Hello Sailor'. Tonight, instead of discussing the existence or non-existence of God, they have decided to fight for it. The existence, or non-existence, to be determined by two falls, two submissions, or a knockout. All right boys, let's get to it. Your master of ceremonies for this evening - Mr Arthur Waring.

I mean, most normal adolescents go through a stage of squeaking two or three times a day. Some youngsters on the other hand, are attracted to it by its very illegality. It's like murder - make a thing illegal and it acquires a mystique. Look at arson - I mean, how many of us can honestly say that at one time or another he hasn't set fire to some great public building. I know I have. text: Grazie signor ... grazie di tutta la sua gentilezza.

text: Well, now, this week we're going to learn some useful phrases to help us open a conversation with an Italian. Now first of all try telling him where you come from. For example, I would say: 'Sono Inglese di Gerrard's Cross', I am an Englishman from Gerrard's Cross. Shall we all try that together?

speaker: All
text: Sono Inglese di Gerrard's Cross.

speaker: Teacher
text: Not too bad, now let's try it with somebody else. Er... Mr... ?

speaker: Mariolini
text: Mariolini.

speaker: Teacher
text: Ah, Mr Mariolini, and where are you from?

speaker: Mariolini
text: Napoli, signor.

speaker: Teacher
text: Ah ... you're an Italian.

speaker: Mariolini
text: Si, si signor!

speaker: Teacher
text: Well in that case you would say: 'Sono Italiano di Napoli'.

speaker: Mariolini
text: Ah, capisco, mile grazie signor...

speaker: Francesco
text: Per favore, signor!

speaker: Teacher
text: Yes?

speaker: Francesco
text: Non conosgeve parliamente, signor devo me parlo sono Italiano di Napoli quando il habitare de Milano.

speaker: Teacher
text: I'm sorry ... I don't understand!

speaker: Giuseppe
text: My friend say 'Why must he say...'

speaker: German
text: Bitte mein Herr. Was ist das Won für Mittelschmerz?

speaker: Teacher
text: Ah! Helmut - you want the German classes.

speaker: German
text: Oh ja! Danke schön. Ah das deutsche Klassenzimmer... Ach!

speaker: Giuseppe
text: My friend he say, 'Why must I say I am Italian from Napoli when he lives in Milan?'

speaker: Teacher
text: Ah, I... well, tell your friend ... if he lives in Milan he must say 'Sono Italiano di Milano...'

speaker: Francesco
text: Eeeeeee! Milano è tanto meglio di Napoli. Milano è la citta la più bella di tutti ... nel mondo...

speaker: Giuseppe
text: He say 'Milan is better than Napoli'.

speaker: Teacher
text: Oh, he shouldn't be saying that, we haven't done comparatives yet.

speaker: Voice Over
text: Yes, mothers, new improved Whizzo butter containing 10% more or less is absolutely indistinguishable from a dead crab. Remember, buy Whizzo butter and go to HEAVEN!

speaker: First Pepperpot
text: I can't tell the difference between Whizzo butter and this dead crab.

speaker: Interviewer
text: Yes, you know, we find that nine out of ten British housewives can't tell the difference between Whizzo butter and a dead crab.

speaker: Pepperpots
text: It's true, we can't. No.

speaker: Second Pepperpot
text: Here. Here! You're on television, aren't you?

speaker: Interviewer
text: Yes, yes.

speaker: Second Pepperpot
text: He does the thing with one of those silly women who can't tell Whizzo butter from a dead crab.

speaker: Third Pepperpot
text: You try that around here, young man, and we'll slit your face.

speaker: Linkman
text: Good evening and welcome to another edition of 'It's the Arts'. And we kick off this evening with the cinema.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Good evening. One of the most prolific film directors of this age, or indeed of any age, is Sir Edward Ross, back in his native country for the first time for five years to open a season of his works at the National Film Theatre, and we are very fortunate to have him with us in this studio this evening.

speaker: Ross
text: Good evening.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Edward... you don't mind if I call you Edward?

speaker: Ross
text: No, not at all.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Only it does worry some people - I don't know why...but they are a little sensitive so I take the precaution of asking on these occasions.

speaker: Ross
text: No, no, no that's fine.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: So Edward's all right. Splendid. Splendid. I'm sorry to have brought it up, only eh...

speaker: Ross
text: No, no, please. Edward it is.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Well thank you very much for being so helpful...only it's more than my job's worth to...er...

speaker: Ross
text: Quite, yes.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Makes it rather difficult to establish a rapport ... to put the other person at his ease...

speaker: Ross
text: Quite.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Yes, silly little point but it does seem to matter. Still - less said the better. Uh...Ted...when you first started in...you don't mind if I call you Ted?

speaker: Ross
text: No, no, no everyone calls me Ted.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Well it's shorter, isn't it.

speaker: Ross
text: Yes it is.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Yes, and much less formal!

speaker: Ross
text: Yes, Ted, Edward, anything!

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Splendid, splendid. Incidentally, do call me Tom, I don't want you playing around with any of this 'Thomas' nonsense! Ha ha ha ha! Now where were we? Ah yes. Eddie-baby, when you first started in the...

speaker: Ross
text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, but I don't like being called 'Eddie-baby'.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: I'm sorry?

speaker: Ross
text: I don't like being called 'Eddie-baby'.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Did I call you 'Eddie-baby'?

speaker: Ross
text: Yes, you did! Now get on with it.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: I don't think I did call you Eddie-baby.

speaker: Ross
text: You did call me Eddie-baby.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: ( ) Did I call him Eddie-baby?

speaker: Voices
text: Yes. No. Yes.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: I didn't really call you Eddie-baby, did I, sweetie?

speaker: Ross
text: Don't call me sweetie!!

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Can I call you sugar plum?

speaker: Ross
text: No!

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Pussy cat?

speaker: Ross
text: No.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Angel-drawers?

speaker: Ross
text: No you may not! Now get on with it!

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Can I call you 'Frank'?

speaker: Ross
text: Why Frank?

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: It's a nice name. Robin Day's got a hedgehog called Frank.

speaker: Ross
text: What is going on?

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Frannie, little Frannie, Frannie Knickers...

speaker: Ross
text: ( ) No. I'm leaving. I'm leaving. I'm off...

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Tell us about your latest film, Sir Edward.

speaker: Ross
text: ( ) What?

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Tell us about your latest film, if you'd be so very kind, Sir Edward.

speaker: Ross
text: None of this 'pussy cat' nonsense?

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Promise. Please, Sir Edward.

speaker: Ross
text: My latest film?

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Yes, Sir Edward.

speaker: Ross
text: Well the idea, funnily enough, came from an idea I had when I first joined the industry in 1919. Of course, in those days I was only the tea boy.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Oh, up.

speaker: Linkman
text: Sir Edward...Ross. Now, later in the programme we will be bringing you a unique event in the world of modern art. Pablo Picasso will be doing a special painting for us, on this programme, live, on a bicycle. But right now it's time to look at a man whose meteoric rise to fame...

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Last week the Royal Festival Hall saw the first performance of a new symphony by one of the world's leading modern composers, Arthur 'Two Sheds' Jackson. Mr Jackson.

speaker: Jackson
text: Good evening.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text:
May I just sidetrack for one moment. Mr. Jackson, this, what shall I call it,
nickname of yours.

speaker: Jackson
text: Ah yes.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: 'Two sheds'. How did you come by it?

speaker: Jackson
text: Well, I don't use it myself, it's just a few of my friends call me 'Two Sheds'.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: I see, and do you in fact have two sheds?

speaker: Jackson
text: No. No, I've only one shed. I've had one for some time, but a few years ago I said I was thinking of getting another one, and since then some people have called me 'Two Sheds'.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: In spite of the fact that you only have one.

speaker: Jackson
text: Yes.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: I see, and are you thinking of purchasing a second shed?

speaker: Jackson
text: No!

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: To bring you in line with your epithet?

speaker: Jackson
text: No.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: I see, I see. Well let's return to your symphony. Ah, now then, did you write this symphony... the shed?

speaker: Jackson
text: No!

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Have you written any of your recent works in this shed of yours?

speaker: Jackson
text: No it's just a perfectly ordinary garden shed.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: I see. And you're thinking of buying this second shed to write in.

speaker: Jackson
text: No, no. Look. This shed business, it doesn't really matter at all, the sheds aren't important. It's just a few friends call me Two Sheds and that's all there is to it. I wish you'd ask me about my music. I'm a composer. People always ask me about the sheds, they've got it out of proportion, I'm fed up with the shed, I wish I'd never got it in the first place.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: I expect you are probably thinking of selling one.

speaker: Jackson
text: I will sell one.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Then you'll be Arthur 'No Sheds' Jackson?

speaker: Jackson
text: Look, forget about the sheds. They don't matter.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Mr. Jackson, I think, with respect, we ought to talk about your symphony.

speaker: Jackson
text: What?

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Apparently your symphony was written for organ and tympani.

speaker: Jackson
text: What's that?

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: What's what?

speaker: Jackson
text: It's a shed. Get it off.

speaker: Jackson
text: Right.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Now then Mr. Jackson...your symphony.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: I understand that you used to be interested in train-spotting.

speaker: Jackson
text: What?

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: I understand that, about thirty years ago, you were extremely interested in train-spotting.

speaker: Jackson
text: What's that got to do with my bloody music?

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Are you having any trouble from him?

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Yes, a little.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Exactly. Well we interviewers are more than a match for the likes of you, 'Two Sheds'.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Yes, make yourself scarce, 'Two Sheds'. This studio isn't big enough for the three of us!

speaker: Jackson
text: What are you doing?

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Get your own Arts programme, you fairy!

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Arthur 'Two Sheds' Jackson.

speaker: Third Interviewer
text: Never mind, Timmy.

speaker: Second Interviewer
text: Oh, Michael, you are such a comfort.

speaker: Linkman
text: Arthur 'Two Sheds'...

speaker: Viking
text: ...Jackson.

speaker: Linkman
text:
And now for more news of the momentous artistic event in which Pablo Picasso is doing a specially commissioned painting for us whilst riding a bicycle. Pablo Picasso - the founder of modern art - without doubt the greatest abstract painter ever... for
the first time painting in motion. But first of all let's have a look at the route he'll be taking.

speaker: Baxter
text: Well Picasso will be starting, David, at Chichester here, he'll then cycle on the A29 to Fontwell, he'll then take the A272 which will bring him on to the A3 just north of Hindhead here. From then on Pablo has a straight run on the A3 until he meets the South Circular at Battersea here. Well, this is a truly remarkable occasion as it is the first time that a modern artist of such stature has taken the A272, and it'll be very interesting to see how he copes with the heavy traffic round Wisborough Green. Vicky.

speaker: Vicky
text: Well Picasso will be riding his Viking Super Roadster with the drop handlebars and the dual-thread wheel-rims and with his Wiley-Prat 20-1 synchro-mesh he should experience difficulties on the sort of road surfaces they just don't get abroad. Mitzie.

speaker: Linkman
text: And now for the latest report on Picasso's progress over to Reg Moss on the Guildford by-pass.

speaker: Reg Moss
text: Well there's no sign of Picasso at the moment, David. But he should be through here at any moment. However I do have with me Mr Ron Geppo, British Cycling Sprint Champion and this year's winner of the Derby-Doncaster rally.

speaker: Geppo
text: Well Reg, I think Pablo should be all right provided he doesn't attempt anything on the monumental scale of some of his earlier paintings, like Guernica or Mademoiselles d'Avignon or even his later War and Peace murals for the Temple of Peace chapel at Vallauris, because with this strong head wind I don't think even Doug Timpson of Manchester Harriers could paint anything on that kind of scale.

speaker: Reg Moss
text: Well, thank you Ron. Well, there still seems to be no sign of Picasso, so I'll hand you back to the studio.

speaker: Linkman
text: Well, we've just heard that Picasso is approaching the Tolworth roundabout on the A3 so come in Sam Trench at Tolworth.

speaker: Trench
text: Well something certainly is happening here at Tolworth roundabout, David. I can now see Picasso, he's cycling down very hard towards the roundabout, he's about 75-50 yards away and I can now see his painting... it's an abstract... I can see some blue some purple and some little black oval shapes... I think I can see...

speaker: Pepperpot
text: That's not Picasso - that's Kandinsky.

speaker: Trench
text: Good lord, you're right. It's Kandinsky. Wassily Kandinsky, and who's this here with him? It's Braque. Georges Braque, the Cubist, painting a bird in flight over a cornfield and going very fast down the hill towards Kingston and... Piet Mondrian - just behind, Piet Mondrian the Neo-Plasticist, and then a gap, then the main bunch, here they come, Chagall, Max Ernst, Miro, Dufy, Ben Nicholson, Jackson Pollock and Bernard Buffet making a break on the outside here, Brancusi's going with him, so is Gericault, Ferdinand Leger, Delaunay, De Kooning, Kokoschka's dropping back here by the look of it, and so's Paul Klee dropping back a bit and, right at the back of this group, our very own Kurt Schwitters..

speaker: Pepperpot
text: He's German!

speaker: Trench
text: But as yet absolutely no sign of Pablo Picasso, and so from Tolworth roundabout back to the studio.

speaker: Linkman
text: Well I think I can help you there Sam, we're getting reports in from the AA that Picasso, Picasso has fallen off...he's fallen off his bicycle on the B2127 just outside Ewhurst, trying to get a short cut through to Dorking via Gomslake and Peashall. Well, Picasso is reported to be unhurt, but the pig has a slight headache. And on that note we must say goodnight to you. Picasso has failed in his first bid for international cycling fame. So from all of us here at the 'It's the Arts' studio, it's goodnight. Goodnight.

speaker: Private
text: Dobson's bought it, sir.

speaker: Officer
text: Porker, eh? Swine.

speaker: Voice Over
text: This man is Ernest Scribbler... writer of jokes. In a few moments, he will have written the funniest joke in the world... and, as a consequence, he will die ... laughing.

speaker: Voice Over
text: It was obvious that this joke was lethal... no one could read it and live ...

speaker: Commentator
text: This morning, shortly after eleven o'clock, comedy struck this little house in Dibley Road. Sudden ...violent ... comedy. Police have sealed off the area, and Scotland Yard's crack inspector is with me now.

speaker: Inspector
text: I shall enter the house and attempt to remove the joke.

speaker: Inspector
text: I shall be aided by the sound of sombre music, played on gramophone records, and also by the chanting of laments by the men of Q Division ... The atmosphere thus created should protect me in the eventuality of me reading the joke.

speaker: Commentator
text: There goes a brave man. Whether he comes out alive or not, this will surely be remembered as one of the most courageous and gallant acts in police history.

speaker: Voice Over
text: It was not long before the Army became interested in the military potential of the Killer Joke. Under top security, the joke was hurried to a meeting of Allied Commanders at the Ministry of War.

speaker: Voice Over
text: Top brass were impressed. Tests on Salisbury Plain confirmed the joke's devastating effectiveness at a range of up to fifty yards.

speaker: Generals
text: Fantastic.

speaker: Colonel
text: All through the winter of '43 we had translators working, in joke-proof conditions, to try and produce a German version of the joke. They worked on one word each for greater safety. One of them saw two words of the joke and spent several weeks in hospital. But apart from that things went pretty quickly, and we soon had the joke by January, in a form which our troops couldn't understand but which the Germans could.

speaker: Voice Over
text: So, on July 8th, 1944, the joke was first told to the enemy in the Ardennes...

speaker: Commanding NCO
text: Tell the ... joke.

speaker: Joke Brigade
text:
Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! ...
     Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput!

speaker: Voice Over
text:
It was a fantastic success. Over sixty thousand times as powerful as
     Britain's great pre-war joke ...

speaker: Voice Over
text: ...and one which Hitler just couldn't match.

speaker: Voice Over
text: In action it was deadly.

speaker: Joke Corporal
text: Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! .. Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput!

speaker: Joke Brigade
text: Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! ... Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput.

speaker: Voice Over
text: The German casualties were appalling.

speaker: Nazi
text: Vott is the big joke?

speaker: Officer
text: I can only give you name, rank, and why did the chicken cross the road?

speaker: Nazi
text: That's not funny! I vant to know the joke.

speaker: Officer
text: All right. How do you make a Nazi cross?

speaker: Nazi
text: I don't know ... how do you make a Nazi cross?

speaker: Officer
text: Tread on his corns.

speaker: Nazi
text: Gott in Himmel! That's not funny! Now if you don't tell me the joke, I shall hit you properly.

speaker: Officer
text: I can stand physical pain, you know.

speaker: Nazi
text: Ah ... you're no fun. All right, Otto.

speaker: Officer
text: Oh no - anything but that please no, all right I'll tell you.

speaker: Nazi
text: Quick Otto. The typewriter.

speaker: Officer
text: Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! ... Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput.

speaker: Nazi
text: Ach! Zat iss not funny!

speaker: Officer
text: Wenn ist das Nunstruck git und Slotermeyer? Ja! ... Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput.

speaker: Voice Over
text: But at Peenemunde in the Autumn of '44, the Germans were working on a joke of their own.

speaker: German Joker
text: Die ist ein Kinnerhunder und zwei Mackel über und der bitte schön ist den Wunderhaus sprechensie. 'Nein' sprecht der Herren 'Ist aufern borger mit zveitingen'.

speaker: Otto
text: We let you know.

speaker: Voice Over
text: But by December their joke was ready, and Hitler gave the order for the German V-Joke to be broadcast in English.

speaker: Radio
text:
Der ver zwei peanuts, valking down der strasse, and von
     vas... assaulted! peanut. Ho-ho-ho-ho.

speaker: Commentator
text: In 1945 Peace broke out. It was the end of the Joke. Joke warfare was banned at a special session of the Geneva Convention, and in 1950 the last remaining copy of the joke was laid to rest here in the Berkshire countryside, never to be told again.

speaker: Announcer
text: And here is the final score: Pigs 9 - British Bipeds 4. The Pigs go on to meet Vicki Carr in the final.
